questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery is the branch of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thyrocervical trunk

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery's first part. The inferior thyroid artery ascends anterior to the medial border of the scalenus anterior, then turns medially just below the sixth cervical transverse process and descends on longus colli to the thyroid gland's lower border.

 

 

The relationships between the terminal branches and the recurrent laryngeal nerve are highly variable and have significant surgical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External Carotid Artery: The external carotid artery supplies most of the structures in the neck, face, scalp, and the upper part of the skull. This artery has several branches, including the superior thyroid, lingual, facial, maxillary, and superficial temporal arteries, among others. While it does supply areas around the thyroid, especially through its superior thyroid branch, it is not the origin of the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Option B. Internal Carotid Artery: The internal carotid artery has no branches in the neck. Instead, it moves upward to supply the brain and eyes. It's essential for cerebral circulation and plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the brain.

 

Option D. Lingual Artery: The lingual artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It supplies the muscles and mucosa of the tongue. Given its role and location, it is not involved in supplying the thyroid gland or associated structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyrocervical trunk is a short branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies numerous structures in the neck. The branches of the thyrocervical trunk are the inferior thyroid artery, the ascending cervical artery, and the transverse cervical artery (which can further divide into superficial and deep branches). The inferior thyroid artery, which arises from the thyrocervical trunk, mainly supplies the thyroid and parathyroid glands.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? (INICET MAY 2018)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  • It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section
  • It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Different guidelines are there for different societies (Both ACOG and SMFM) recommend pneumatic compression devices for all patients undergoing cesarean section. This table is from Williams and shows the different guidelines:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatic compression devices are used for thromboembolism prevention in women undergoing cesarean sections, whether or not they are on thromboprophylaxis, and are discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.

 

Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3>2>1

 

  • Curve 1 exhibits the smallest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, and then Curve 3. Thus, the ranking is as follows: 3>2>1.
  • The depicted image showcases three normal distribution curves with varying sample sizes, all sharing the same mean but differing in standard deviation.
  • When the sample size decreases, the peak diminishes, and the curve adopts a flatter shape.
  • This signifies a broader confidence interval for the specified mean.
  • The width of the curve's base is directly linked to the margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen’s chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium

 

Animals that consume grains containing 5 to 40 mg selenium/kg over a period of several weeks or months suffer from chronic selenosis, known as alkali disease. Signs include liver cirrhosis, lameness, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation.

 

 It is associated with loss of hair on the mane and tail, hoof deformities, and decreased reproductive performance1. It is caused by toxicity from eating plants or grain with protein-bound, insoluble selenium2. This disease normally occurs in cattle and sheep feeding on seleniferous plants

 

Selenium intoxication can also be acute and subacute (blind staggers type).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manganese:

  • Deficiency: Manganese deficiency can lead to skeletal abnormalities, reproductive issues, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess manganese is rare and typically does not cause a condition similar to alkali disease.

 

Option C. Molybdenum:

  • Deficiency: Molybdenum deficiency can impair the function of molybdoenzymes, leading to metabolic disturbances.
  • Excess: Excess molybdenum can interfere with copper metabolism, leading to copper deficiency (known as molybdenosis) in livestock, characterized by symptoms such as diarrhea, poor growth, and anemia.

 

Option D. Iron:

  • Deficiency: Iron deficiency can lead to anemia, weakness, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess iron can cause toxicity, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of alkali disease. Iron toxicity is more likely to result in gastrointestinal disturbances and liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkali disease in livestock is caused by chronic selenium toxicity, leading to liver cirrhosis, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation. This condition is distinct from the effects of other mineral toxicities or deficiencies.

questions.text: The procedure in the image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure used for? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

  • Methylene blue dye, along with other tracers, is commonly employed in sentinel lymph node biopsy procedures. Sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that cancer is likely to spread to from a primary tumor. By injecting the dye around the tumor, these sentinel lymph nodes can be identified and biopsied to determine if cancer has spread to them. This helps in staging and planning further treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLN biopsy rationale:

 

Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node, before draining into the other nodes.

 

So, if sentinel lymph node is positive, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.

 

If the sentinel node is tumor free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

 

The nodes can be identified using:

 

  • Fluorescein dye
  • Methylene blue
  • Radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin

 

The recommended site of injection is in the subdermal plexus surrounding the nipple.

 

This is used in patients with clinically node-negative disease.

questions.text: 60-year-old lady presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Her family says she was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. ECG on arrival is suggestive of Anterior wall MI. Her son succumbed to Severe COVID-19 pneumonia. CAG showed normal epicardial coronaries. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress.

 

Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure. Beta2 (Gs stimulation) at base and Beta2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimic ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No signs of infection/Inflammation are given in the history. In presence of stress and temporal association, infection less likely.

 

Option C. Normal CAG rules out significant macrovascular CAD.

 

Option D. HCM shows dagger like q waves, SAM, Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy on ECHO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms and ECG changes similar to those of an acute myocardial infarction, but it is distinguished by normal coronary arteries on angiography and is often precipitated by severe emotional stress, fitting the patient's recent personal history.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259.

questions.text: Acid mucin is stained by _______? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcian blue

 

MUCIN STAINS:

 

  1. Alcian blue: Stains acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-simple mesenchymal mucins, acid-complex sulfated mucins and acid-complex connective tissue mucins. Does NOT stain neutral mucins
  2. Colloidal iron: Stains acid-simple non-sulfated, acid-simple mesenchymal, acid-complex sulfated mucins. Does NOT stain neutral mucins or acid-complex connective tissue mucins
  3. Mucicarmine: Very specific for epithelial mucins, including adenocarcinomas
  4. PAS (periodic acid-Schiff): Stains glycogen as well as mucins, but tissue can be pre-digested with diastase to remove glycogen. Stains neutral and acid-simple non-sulfated and acid-complex sulfated mucins. Does NOT stain acid-simple mesenchymal mucins and acid-complex connective tissue mucins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAS: Stains both glycogen and mucins, but is not as specific as Alcian blue for acid mucins.

 

Option C. Masson trichrome: Primarily used for staining connective tissue (collagen) and is not specific for mucins.

 

Option D. PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin): Typically used for staining muscle striations, fibrin, and glial fibers, not for mucins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcian blue is the preferred stain for identifying acid mucins in tissue samples, distinguishing it from other stains that target different types of mucins or tissue components.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Febuxostat

 

Febuxostat is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor primarily used as a hypouricemic agent for managing gout by reducing uric acid production. Its primary function is to alleviate the symptoms and prevent the recurrence of gout, not to treat inflammatory or autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Incorrect choice for the given answer as Leflunomide is indeed used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that works by suppressing the immune system to reduce inflammation.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Incorrect because Methotrexate is a cornerstone treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. It is another DMARD that helps reduce joint damage and decrease the pain and swelling associated with RA.

 

Option D. Etanercept: Incorrect as it is also used in rheumatoid arthritis treatment. Etanercept is a TNF (tumor necrosis factor) inhibitor, which is a type of biologic therapy that helps to decrease inflammation and slow disease progression in RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febuxostat is specifically used to manage gout by lowering uric acid levels and does not have a role in the treatment regimen for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically involves DMARDs and biologic agents aimed at controlling systemic inflammation and preventing joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap 358

questions.text: Given the particular appearance and characteristics of the box-whisker plot as shown below, which of the following statements most accurately describes the relationships between the mean, median, and mode? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mean > Median > Mode 

 

  • The provided box-whisker plot illustrates a distribution that is positively skewed (right skewed).
  • In a positively skewed distribution, the mean > median > mode.
  • To further understand and correlate the fact, have a look at the following images:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Right skew curve: Mean > Median > Mode
  • In Left skew curve: Mean < Median < Mode
  • In Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

choices.text: 3 swab test

questions.text: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). It allows direct visualization of the bladder and can help identify the exact location, size, and number of fistulas. Additionally, cystoscopy can be used to assess the bladder for any associated injuries or other abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 3 swab test: This test is used to identify the type of genitourinary fistula (vesicovaginal or ureterovaginal) but is not as specific as cystoscopy for visualizing the fistula directly.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic structures and help in the diagnosis of fistulas, it is not the first-line investigation. It is more useful in complex cases or when additional information is needed.

 

Option D. Cystometry: This test evaluates bladder filling and voiding problems and is not specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for directly visualizing vesicovaginal fistulas, determining their size, location, and number, and assessing the bladder for any associated injuries.

 

Ref: Page no 417, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

 

Syndrome Z also known as Metabolic Syndrome, is characterized by a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Syndrome involve the pressence of any three of the following five traits: 

 

Any 3/5 for diagnosis:

 

  1. Central Obesity: > 102cm (M),> 88 cm (F); [90(M), 80 cm (F) in Indians]: Only if questions specifically mention Indian population.
  2. BP > 130/85 mmHg
  3. FBS > 100 mg/dL/A1c
  4. Low HDL (in mg/dL): < 40 (F), < 50 cm(M)
  5. High TGL: > 150 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

questions.text: As a Medical Officer at a Community Health Center (CHC), you're consulted by a mother about starting immunizations for her 13-month-old son who hasn't received any vaccines since birth. Based on the national immunization schedule, which combination of vaccines would you recommend for this child's initial immunization? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV 1st dose, DPT 1st dose, Measles 1st dose

 

  • DPT-1, OPV-1 and Measles 1st dose will be given to this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Its activity is increased in the fed state and decreased during fasting. During fasting, the body's metabolic state shifts to prioritize gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, leading to a decrease in glycolytic enzyme activities, including PFK-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Mobilizes fatty acids from adipose tissue by breaking down triglycerides.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and muscles, providing glucose during fasting.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

Collagen III is the first to be synthesized in the early stages of wound healing and is replaced by collagen I, the dominant skin collagen. Initially there is random deposition of collagen during the granulation tissue formation which is further enhanced by enzyme-induced covalent cross-linking. This process matures the collagen into complex structures that are reoriented for tensile strength restoration. Collagen remodeling continues for months after wound closure and the tensile strength of the repaired tissue increases to about 80–85% of normal tissue if all processes proceed without any perturbations.

 

Note –

  • Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissue.

 

  • Type I is the most abundant form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type II:

  • Location: Found primarily in cartilage and the vitreous humor of the eye.
  • Function: Provides structural support to cartilage and vitreous body.
  • Disease: Deficiency leads to severe chondrodysplasias and osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Type IV:

  • Location: Found in basement membranes.
  • Function: Provides structural integrity to the basement membrane.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Alport syndrome.

 

Option D. Type V:

  • Location: Found as a minor component in tissues containing collagen I.
  • Function: Contributes to the regulation of collagen fibril assembly.
  • Disease: Deficiency causes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type I (EDS-I).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in adults? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1-L2

 

Explanation:

 

Termination of the Spinal Cord:

 

  • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris.
  • Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance.
  • Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L3-L4: This is incorrect as the spinal cord in adults does not extend to this level. This level is generally where lumbar punctures are performed to avoid the spinal cord.

 

Option C. T12-L1: This is slightly higher than the actual end of the spinal cord in adults. The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2, not T12-L1.

 

Option D. L2-L3: This is incorrect as well because the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults, not extending to L2-L3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spinal cord in adults terminates at the lower border of L1, at the region called the conus medullaris, with the cauda equina continuing downward from this point.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1414

choices.text: Response- Mitigation- Reconstruction- Rehabilitation- Preparedness
Mitigation- Rehabilitation- Reconstruction- Preparedness- response
Response- Rehabilitation- Reconstruction- Mitigation- Preparedness
Mitigation- Preparedness- Reconstruction- Rehabilitation- Response

questions.text: As a physician on a disaster preparedness committee in a region prone to natural disasters, you are discussing the appropriate sequence of actions following a disaster. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the appropriate steps in disaster management after the event has taken place? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction – Mitigation – Preparedness

 

The correct sequence after a disaster as per the general disaster management principles is:

 

  1. Response: Immediate actions taken to ensure safety, provide emergency services, and stabilize the situation. This involves –
  • Search, rescue and first aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead
  1. Rehabilitation: Short-term recovery and normalization of operations to restore basic services and functions in the affected area.
  2. Reconstruction: Long-term rebuilding of infrastructure and restoration of a fully functional community.
  3. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the risk and lessen the impact of future disasters.
  4. Preparedness: Planning and preparation to improve response activities for future disasters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disaster Cycle

choices.text: Colposcopy with LEEP

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy with LEEP

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN 3) is a severe form of cervical dysplasia that is diagnosed by cervical biopsy. The standard treatment for CIN 2 or CIN 3 is an excisional procedure, which aims to remove the affected tissue to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

 

  • LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):
    • LEEP is the excisional procedure of choice for treating CIN 3.
    • It involves using a thin wire loop that is heated by electric current to excise the transformation zone of the cervix where abnormal cells are located.
    • LEEP is also known as LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It is generally not the first-line treatment for CIN 3 unless there are other indications, such as concurrent invasive cancer or other gynecological conditions.

 

Option B. Trachelectomy: This procedure involves removing the cervix while preserving the uterus. It is more commonly used for early-stage cervical cancer in women who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Option C. Conization: While conization (removal of a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix) is a valid treatment for CIN 3, LEEP is often preferred due to its effectiveness and lower morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIN 3 is best treated with an excisional procedure, with the Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP) being the procedure of choice.

 

Ref: Page no 328, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of salbutamol?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

 

Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist that is used as a Short Acting Bronchodilator in the relief of acute exacerbations from asthma.

 

It can lead to tachycardia (due to stimulation of the β1 receptors at large doses), Hypokalemia and development of tolerance on long term use due to desensitization of its receptors and in large doses can lead to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: This is a known side effect of salbutamol due to its action on β2 receptors, which increase potassium uptake into cells, resulting in lower serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Tremors: These are a common side effect of salbutamol due to β2 receptor stimulation in skeletal muscles, leading to muscle tremors.

 

Option D. Tachycardia: Salbutamol, especially at higher doses, can stimulate β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increased heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salbutamol can cause hypokalemia, tremors, and tachycardia, but it does not cause hypoglycemia. Instead, it can lead to hyperglycemia due to its effect on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Consolidation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient complaining of fever and cough with positive air bronchogram sign on chest x-ray suggests lobar consolidation which is most commonly due to Pneumococcal pneumonia.

 

Air bronchogram refers to the phenomenon of air-filled bronchi (dark) being made visible by the opacification of surrounding alveoli (grey/white). It is almost always caused by a pathologic airspace/alveolar process, in which something other than air fills the alveoli. 

 

The causes of air bronchogram are as follows:

  • Pulmonary consolidation
  • Pulmonary Edema: especially with alveolar edema 
  • Neoplasms: bronchioloalveolar carcinoma; pulmonary lymphoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural effusion: Would typically show blunting of the costophrenic angles and a fluid level on the chest X-ray, not associated with air bronchograms.

 

Option B. Hilar lymphadenopathy: Presents as enlarged hilar shadows on X-ray, which do not include the air bronchogram sign.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Characterized by permanent dilation of parts of the airways of the lung; air bronchograms can be present but are more commonly associated with acute infections or consolidations.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The air bronchogram sign on a chest X-ray, indicative of the presence of air within the bronchi surrounded by opacified alveoli, is a classic feature of pulmonary consolidation, most commonly seen in pneumococcal pneumonia.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of a disease that is characterized by the occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drugs

 

Adverse drug reactions can lead to a condition known as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or its more severe form, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN), where there is extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membrane involvement. This severe reaction typically involves over 30% of the body surface area in TEN. It is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening. The implicated drugs often include allopurinol, certain anticonvulsants, sulphonamide antibiotics, and NSAIDs, among others.

 

As more than 30% of the body surface is involved, the diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Clinical picture will be as shown in the image below.

 

 

SJS Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis classification based on BSA involvement:

 

Based on body surface area (BSA):  

 

 

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

 

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

 

  • Allopurinol
  • Carbamazepine
  • Lamotrigine
  • Nevirapine
  • Oxicam (Non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs)
  • Phenobarbital
  • Phenytoin
  • Sulfamethoxazole and other sulfa antibiotics
  • Sulfasalazine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral Infection: Viral infections can indeed cause skin rashes and even blistering in some cases, such as with herpes viruses, including Varicella-zoster virus and Herpes simplex virus. However, they rarely lead to a condition with widespread blistering affecting over 30% of the body surface area.

 

Option C. Fungal Infection: Fungal infections typically cause localized skin changes such as rashes, scaling, and sometimes blistering, but these are usually limited in scope and do not affect such a large proportion of the skin surface as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Auto-immunity: Autoimmune diseases like pemphigus vulgaris can cause blistering, but they do not usually result in acute widespread skin peeling over 30% of the body surface area. The blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are more superficial and often rupture easily, not typically resulting in extensive peeling.

 

In conclusion, when presented with widespread blistering and peeling of such a significant portion of the skin, drug reactions should be the first consideration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area is most commonly associated with severe drug reactions, such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition, Chapter 119, Page no 119.13

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter.

 

Acinetobacter species are particularly prevalent in hospital settings and are a common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). These organisms are known for their ability to survive on surfaces for extended periods and their resistance to multiple antibiotics, making them a significant concern in intensive care units where patients are often intubated. Acinetobacter, along with Pseudomonas and Stenotrophomonas, is known for colonizing the respiratory tract of ventilated patients, leading to VAP, which typically occurs after 48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: This genus, including species like Clostridium difficile, is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, rather than pneumonia.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, it is generally less common than Acinetobacter in this specific infection context. Klebsiella tends to be more associated with community-acquired pneumonia and hospital-acquired infections outside of the ventilator context.

 

Option D. Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections but is more commonly linked to community-acquired pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rather than VAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acinetobacter, pseudomonas, stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia cepacia are common organisms causing VAP. VAP occurs due to colonization by organisms in < 48 hours.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Pneumonia/Chap 142

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rheumatoid arthritis

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
      • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    1. Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    2. Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint, upper cervical spine
    3. Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
      • Usually, DIP is not involved. It is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
      • Lumbar spine is spared.
      • Others: The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children. Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heberden's nodes on pre-existing osteoarthritis. Heberden’s nad Bouchard’s nodes are firm swellings over the superolateral and dorsal aspects of DIP and PIP joints respectively. Lateral view of the x-ray of the hand reveals large exostoses arising from the proximal ends of the distal phalanges in the attachment of extensor and flexor tendons. They may begin as small, round, fluctuant, tender mass, a little to one side of the dorsum of the joint.

 

 

 

Option C. Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints. Tenosynovitis is quite common, but it is generally not a striking or isolated clinical complaint. The most common sites are the extensor tendon sheaths on the dorsum of the hand, the extensor sheaths over the dorsum of the foot, and those of the posterior tibial tendon and the peroneus longus and brevis tendons. If tenosynovitis is very prominent, Blau syndrome should be considered. Triggering or loss of extension of the fingers may result from a stenosing synovitis of the flexor tendon sheaths.

 

 

Option D. Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome. CRPS is characterized by a chronic neurological disorder involving upper or lower limbs after any type of injury or surgery. In some cases, it occurs spontaneously. Sensory and autonomic disturbances are the main features of this syndrome (allodynia or hyperalgesia, edema, changes in skin blood flow or abnormal sudomotor activity) and are disproportionate to the starting event. The underlying mechanism is still unknown. Multiple mechanisms considered to play a role in the generation and maintenance of CRPS includes biofeedback from autonomic nervous system, alterations of central nervous system, neurogenic inflammation and immunological mechanisms. There is no specific diagnostic test for CRPS. History, clinical examination, symptoms and signs of the patient are the main aspects to be considered for a correct diagnosis. CRPS does not have a pathognomonic sign. The key symptom is prolonged pain that may be constant and disproportionate to the initial injury. The characteristics of the pain are continuous, spontaneous or episodic. Patients frequently described this symptom as burning. The distal part of the limb is the most common area and the typical clinical manifestations are red skin, pain, and swelling. Symptoms may change over time and vary from patient to patient. Over time the injured limb can became pale, cold and in addition muscle spasm and tightening can appear. This condition is often irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image and the symptoms in a female of pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand, morning stiffness with problem in squatting is clinical for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

 

The Nile blue test is a laboratory test used to assess fetal lung maturity by staining desquamated fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid. The correct interpretation of this test is that if more than 50% of the cells stain orange, it indicates pulmonary maturity. Therefore, the presence of more than 50% blue cells, as mentioned in Option D, suggests immature lungs rather than maturity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio > 2.0: The Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is a well-established method for assessing fetal lung maturity. A ratio greater than 2.0 typically indicates mature fetal lungs.

 

Option B. Positive shake test: The shake test, also known as the foam stability test, assesses the presence of surfactant in amniotic fluid. A positive shake test, indicated by the formation of stable bubbles, suggests fetal lung maturity.

 

Option C. Increased phosphatidyl glycerol: The presence of phosphatidylglycerol in amniotic fluid is another indicator of lung maturity, particularly in pregnancies complicated by diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:


The presence of more than 50% orange cells in the Nile blue test indicates fetal lung maturity, whereas more than 50% blue cells suggest immaturity.

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

choices.text: At the onset of labor
40 weeks

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with cardiac disease involves switching from warfarin to heparin at specific times to minimize the risk of complications to the fetus and to prepare for delivery.

 

  • Switch to Heparin at 36 Weeks: According to guidelines from the American College of Chest Physicians, pregnant women on warfarin therapy should switch to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation. This is done to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

 

Guidelines Summary:

 

  1. Early Pregnancy (up to 12 weeks):
    • Discontinue warfarin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed, especially if the warfarin dose is >5mg/day, due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy.
    • Replace with heparin (5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).
  2. After 12 Weeks to 36 Weeks:
    • Warfarin can be resumed after the 12th week and continued up to 36 weeks.
  3. At 36 Weeks:
    • Switch from warfarin to heparin (either unfractionated or LMWH).
  4. Just Before Delivery:
    • Discontinue heparin just before delivery.
  5. Postpartum:
    • Restart heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after cesarean section.
    • Warfarin therapy can also be safely resumed during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The final switch from warfarin to heparin in pregnant women with cardiac disease is advised at 36 weeks of gestation to minimize the risk of bleeding complications during labor and delivery.

questions.text: A bashful young man who prefers social solitude appears emotionally frigid and lives alone. There is no history of delusions or hallucinations. The most likely explanation is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Schizoid personality disorder is marked by detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals prefer solitude and appear emotionally cold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paranoid personality disorder: It is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others. They may be excessively sensitive and give excessive importance to themselves. The vignette described above does not mention suspiciousness, infact mentions there is no history of delusions. Hence the answer is not paranoid personality disorder.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder: These patients disregard others' rights and frequently violates them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviours such as theft, conning etc. 

 

Option D. Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Otherwise known as Borderline personality disorder. They are almost always in the state of crisis. They have a history of unstable relationships and emotions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by detachment from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and are indifferent to praise or criticism. There is also an absence of close relationships. It is classified as a Cluster A personality disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2152

questions.text: What type of connective tissue is found in the region indicated by the black arrow in the provided image? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense irregular

 

In the provided image, the black arrow points to a region with a meshwork of collagen fibers. This pattern is characteristic of dense irregular connective tissue, which is identified by its densely packed collagen fibers that are arranged in an irregular, haphazard fashion. This type of connective tissue provides strength and support and allows the skin to resist multidirectional forces. It is typically found in areas that require strength and rigidity, such as the dermis of the skin, which is what is likely being shown in this histological slide.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dense regular connective tissue features collagen fibers that are parallel to each other, conferring tensile strength in one particular direction. It is typically found in tendons and ligaments, where the force is exerted in a single direction as shown in the image below.

 

 

This is not what we see in the image, where the fibers are not arranged in parallel.

 

Irregular and Regular connective tissue

 

 

Option C. Loose regular connective tissue is not a recognized classification.

 

Option D. Loose irregular connective tissue is also not a recognized classification. What is commonly known is loose connective tissue (also termed areolar connective tissue), which has a much looser fiber arrangement and a lot of ground substance, often found beneath epithelial layers, surrounding blood vessels, and nerves. It has a different appearance from what is indicated by the arrow in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image shows dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by a dense network of collagen fibers arranged in an irregular pattern, commonly found in the dermis of the skin, providing strength and the ability to resist multi-directional forces.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystine

 

Cystine stones are resistant to extracorporal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) due to their hardness. Cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most refractory to SWL fragmentation, with cystine and brushite being the most resistant.

 

Cystine stones are known to be resistant to ESWL. These stones are composed of cystine, an amino acid, and they have a dense and crystalline structure that makes them less responsive to shock wave treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Struvite: Struvite stones are generally responsive to ESWL. They often contain magnesium and ammonia and can be fragmented successfully with shock waves. However, when they attain large size and form staghorn shape, ESWL is not performed.

 

Option C. Calcium oxalate dihydrate: ESWL is often effective for calcium oxalate dihydrate stones. These stones are one of the most common types, and their composition typically allows for successful fragmentation with shock waves.

 

Option D. Uric Acid: Uric acid stones are also responsive to ESWL. These stones are composed of uric acid crystals and can be effectively broken down using shock wave lithotripsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 2 cm in size can be treated with this form of treatment.

 

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma.

 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients on oral anticoagulants.

 

Note: Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estrogen

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, the granulosa cells of the developing follicles secrete high amounts of estrogen, specifically estradiol. This phase is characterized by the development of a primordial follicle to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles. The following events occur during this phase:

 

  • Estrogen Secretion: Granulosa cells secrete increasing amounts of estrogen, primarily estradiol, which causes proliferation of the endometrium in preparation for potential implantation.
  • Up-regulation of Receptors: LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in both theca and granulosa cells.
  • Feedback Mechanism: The rising estradiol levels exert a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary, suppressing the secretion of FSH and LH to moderate levels.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles but is not secreted by granulosa cells.

 

Option C. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and plays a role in the later stages of follicle development and ovulation.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum after ovulation during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, ovarian granulosa cells secrete high amounts of estrogen, which is crucial for the proliferation of the endometrium and regulation of FSH and LH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 78, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In what situations does Gelle's test yield a negative result?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis

 

  • Gelle's test is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed as in case of otosclerosis.
  • Gelle's test –  Increased pressure in the ear canal by Siegel's speculum, pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards raising the intralabyrinthine pressure and reducing the mobility of the basilar membrane leading to decreased hearing. This is called as Gelle’s positive seen in normal and SNHL patients.
  • No change in hearing on applying pressure is Gelle’s negative, seen in ossicular chain fixation or discontinuity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM with Cholesteatoma: In case of CSOM with cholesteatoma, the pressure increased by the seigel’s speculum will directly push the cholesteatoma onto the ossicles (there is no fixation of ossicles here) and then there will be increased intralabyrinthine pressure. Hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option B. Senile deafness: In case of senile deafness (presbycusis), there will be sensorineural hearing loss and it is due to natural aging of the hair cells. The ossicles will be mobile normally and hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: In case of Meniere’s disease also, the ossicles are not involved. On siegelisation, the inward pushed TM and ossicles will raise intralabyrinthine pressure, thereby making Gelle test positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gelle’s test is instrumental in diagnosing conditions involving ossicular chain mobility. A negative Gelle's test, indicating ossicular fixation, is particularly indicative of otosclerosis, which is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies, including potential surgical interventions like stapedectomy for improving hearing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

The correct choice is B, Dexamethasone, because the symptoms described (fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates) suggest the patient may be experiencing differentiation syndrome, which can occur following the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with agents like Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by such symptoms and can improve with the administration of Dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is also used intrathecally in children for treating Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), indicating its relevance in managing severe inflammatory reactions in hematological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: This option is incorrect as Cytarabine is primarily used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia and not specifically indicated for the management of differentiation syndrome in APML.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Incorrect because Doxorubicin is utilized for its efficacy against various cancers including Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the breast, and thyroid but is not suitable for treating differentiation syndrome in APML. It is also known for its cardiotoxic effects.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Incorrect as it is not recommended in the treatment regimen for APML and does not address the immediate complications of differentiation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

 

Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is the diagnosis in this case, which is characterized by an open, inside-out bladder on the surface of the lower abdominal wall, and an exposed dorsal urethra. The pathogenesis of this condition is thought to be due to an embryological defect in abdominal wall development. In affected females, there is epispadias with bifid clitoris and small, laterally displaced labia minora, while in affected males, there is epispadias as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrochisis: The abdominal contents will be out and not covered in a sac.

 

 

 

Option C. Superior vesical fissure: A defect of closure in the infra-umbilical abdominal wall through which vesical mucous membrane protruded. A probe introduced into the urethra appeared externally at the place of the infraumbilical defect. Following the diagnosis of superior vesical fissure, resection of the protruding vesical mucous membrane and closure were carried out.

 

Option D. Anterior ectopic anus: The above features and image doesn’t correlate with the mentioned findings in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

choices.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group
Matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells
Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis

questions.text: About giant-cell tumor, all are true except:(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. 
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
    • The proliferative component of a giant cell tumor (GCT) is primarily made up of the mononuclear stromal cells, which are mesenchymal in origin.
    • These stromal cells are the neoplastic (tumor-forming) cells of GCT and play a central role in tumor growth and aggressiveness.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. 
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. 
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of multinucleated giant cells (40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). 
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors commonly presents in the 20-40 years of age group. 
  • Microscopically, the matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells.
  • Osteoclast giant cells induce the proliferation of the monoculcear macrophage cells, increasing the mononuclear cell population. 
  • It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis in about 4% cases.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate were >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Check Blood sugar level

 

Evaluation of Common reversible emergency causes are targeted in the ER. Altered mental status occurring acutely can be remembered with MIST.

 

Step 1. Rx >>> Dx priority (↓ Glucose).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HTN emergency is treated with I.V. antihypertensives.

 

Option C. I.V. mannitol is used in the management of cerebral edema.

 

Option D. CT brain to be done after ruling out life-threatening reversible common causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of any comatose patient, particularly those with diabetes, should include rapid assessment of blood glucose levels to rule out hypo- or hyperglycemia as a reversible cause of the coma. This immediate action can be life-saving and should precede other investigations and treatments.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E2VNTM3.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury and other conditions. In this scenario, the patient is intubated, which affects the ability to assess the verbal response. The current nomenclature for denoting non-testability due to intubation is "NT" (Non-testable) for the verbal component.

 

  • Eye Opening (E): The patient opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, which scores 2.
  • Verbal Response (V): The verbal component is non-testable (NT) due to intubation.
  • Motor Response (M): The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate response), which scores 3.

 

This combination gives a GCS score of E2VNTM3.

 

 

NT = non-testability of the corresponding component.

 

Used mainly in acute TBI (Traumatic brain injury).

 

Update:

 

1. GCS-P Score takes pupillary activity into consideration.

 

P = Pupillary non-reactivity

 

2 = Both pupil

 

1 = One pupil

 

0 = None

 

Minimum = 1, Max = 15.

 

2. FOUR score (Full outline of unresponsiveness) is currently employed having better sensitivity, specificity and PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intubated patients, the GCS verbal score is marked as "NT" for non-testable. The GCS remains a vital tool in assessing the level of consciousness, particularly in emergency and critical care settings, ensuring that changes in the patient’s neurological status are promptly recognized and appropriately managed.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Basics /Chapter 443-TBI

questions.text: You are assessing the impact of a new series testing protocol on the performance characteristics of diagnostic tests for a specific disease. You need to explain to your team how this method affects the test's sensitivity and specificity. What would be the correct explanation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN SERIES:

 

A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test; 2nd screening test is applied on those individuals only who test positive on the 1st screening test

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in series: Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in series: [Specificity (A) + Specificity (B)] – [Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)]

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN PARALLEL:

 

A population is subjected to two (or more) screening tests at the same time; each of the individuals is subjected to both (or all) screening tests

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: [Sensitivity (A) + Sensitivity (B)] – [Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)]
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his ETCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

 

Explanation:

 

Venous Air Embolism:

 

  • Definition: It refers to the entry of air into the venous system, which can then travel to the heart and block the pulmonary circulation.
  • Presentation: A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. A "mill wheel" murmur might be heard on auscultation.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The sudden drop in ETCO2, combined with hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia following manipulation of the internal jugular vein during surgery in a head-up position, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

There are four important events here:

  1. Bleeding from the internal jugular vein (severed vein which can entrap air)
  2. A drastic fall in ETCO2
  3. Hypotension
  4. Neck surgery – requires head-up position which reduces blood pressure in neck veins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sympathetic Overactivity:

  • Definition: It refers to excessive stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Presentation: It typically manifests as hypertension (raised blood pressure) and tachycardia (increased heart rate).
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The patient developed hypotension, not hypertension, so this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Vagal Stimulation:

  • Definition: Activation of the vagus nerve, one of the cranial nerves, which plays a role in controlling the heart, lungs, and digestive tract.
  • Presentation: Vagal stimulation can cause bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and hypotension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: While vagal stimulation can explain the hypotension and arrhythmia, it does not account for the drastic drop in ETCO2.

 

Option D. Carotid Body Stimulation:

  • Definition: The carotid body is a small cluster of chemoreceptors located at the bifurcation of the carotid artery. It monitors changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • Presentation: Stimulation can cause changes in heart rate and blood pressure, but it typically results in hypertension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: Given that the patient is hypotensive, this option is less likely.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias during surgery, especially involving the internal jugular vein and head-up positioning, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1878-1880

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with a history of cholelithiasis, presented with vomiting and abdominal pain. The abdominal radiograph showed Rigler's triad. Which of these is not a component of Rigler's triad? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Large bowel obstruction

 

Rigler's triad is a radiologic finding associated with gallstone ileus, consisting of three specific signs: pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), small bowel obstruction, and an ectopic calcified gallstone, typically found in the right iliac fossa. These findings are indicative of a gallstone that has passed into the intestinal tract via a biliary-enteric fistula and is causing an obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumobilia: Correctly identified as a part of Rigler's triad, indicating the presence of air within the biliary system due to a fistula between the biliary tree and the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Small Bowel Obstruction: Also a component of Rigler's triad, typically caused by the ectopic gallstone blocking the small intestine.

 

Option C. Ectopic Gall Stone: Another correct component of Rigler's triad, representing the gallstone that has migrated and is causing obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigler triad consists of three findings seen in gallstone ileus:

 

  • Pneumobilia
  • Small Bowel Obstruction
  • Ectopic calcified gallstone, usually in the right iliac fossa

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

 

Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

 

The Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV), belongs to the family of DNA viruses Herpeseviridae. It causes Kaposi sarcoma (a vascular malignancy) and B cell lymphoproliferative diseases such as primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD).

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

 

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is catalase-positive and does not typically exhibit bacitracin sensitivity. It is identified by coagulase testing and its ability to grow in the presence of high salt concentrations.

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod and is not identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Bacillus species are Gram-positive rods that form spores and are not typically identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

questions.text:
The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition? (AIIMS May 2018)

 

Note: The solid line is the original fluid compartment the dotted line denotes the change caused by the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenal Insufficiency

 

Darrow Yannet diagrams are graphs that tell you the osmolarity and volume changes of body fluids. X axis represents volume. Y axis represents solute concentration.

 

 

 

Addison's disease is adrenal insufficiency. Aldosterone makes you retain sodium so in the absence of aldosterone, you will lose sodium.) so osmolarity of ECF will decrease. ECF volume will decrease as fluid will move from ECF to ICF, thus ICF volume will increase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive sweating: Generally leads to both sodium and water loss, reducing volume but potentially increasing or maintaining osmolarity.

 

Option C. Diarrhoea: Also causes loss of water and electrolytes but usually does not lead to a significant increase in ICF volume.

 

Option D. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone): Causes hyponatremia and increased ECF volume, opposite to what is seen in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenal insufficiency leads to a decrease in ECF volume and osmolarity due to loss of sodium and water, prompting a compensatory increase in ICF volume. This is visualized in the Darrow Yannet diagram by the shift from a higher solute concentration and volume to lower levels in the ECF and an increase in the ICF.

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endemic 

 

  • The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic

 

  • Endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
    • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
    • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic: Incorrect because an epidemic refers to an increase in the number of cases of a disease beyond what is normally expected in that population in that area. The current case count does not exceed the usual range.

 

Option C. Sporadic: Incorrect because sporadic refers to a disease that occurs infrequently and irregularly; here, the cases are neither infrequent nor irregular.

 

Option D. Outbreak: Similar to an epidemic, an outbreak implies a greater-than-anticipated increase in the number of cases within a small, localized area over a short period. Again, since the case count is within normal expectations, this term does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proprioception

 

Explanation:

 

Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature: Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.
