Option B. Pain: Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Touch: Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

questions.text: The following image indicates: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor palsy

 

The given image suggests oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements, it can be seen that adduction, elevation, and depression are absent in the left eye.

 

All of these findings indicate oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis: This is due to the weakness of the levator muscle.
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out"): This is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest: This is due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction: This is due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation: This is due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression: This is due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation: This is due to parasympathetic palsy.
  • Normal abduction: This is due to the intact lateral rectus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve palsy: Primarily affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and head tilt but does not cause ptosis or pupil involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral rectus palsy: Would lead to medial deviation of the eye due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle, affecting horizontal eye movement.

 

Option C. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: Characterized by impairment of horizontal eye movements, particularly affecting the adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion, with nystagmus in the abducting eye, typically not involving the eyelid or pupil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor palsy involves multiple dysfunctions including ptosis, "down and out" eye position, and possibly a dilated pupil. Recognizing the full range of symptoms is critical for a correct diagnosis, indicating a comprehensive evaluation of cranial nerve III integrity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

choices.text: Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition
Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis
Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition
Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

 

All of the above Antifungal agents are correctly matched with their corresponding mechanisms of action except for Flucytosine. Flucytosine acts by inhibiting the synthesis of nucleic acid. Griseofulvin is the antifungal that acts by inhibiting microtubule synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition

Ketoconazole is correctly matched. It inhibits lanosterol-14-demethylase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, which is a crucial component of the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition

Terbinafine is correctly matched. It inhibits squalene epoxidase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of squalene and cell death.

 

Option D. Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

Amphotericin B is correctly matched. It binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that increase membrane permeability and cause cell contents to leak out, leading to cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flucytosine inhibits nucleic acid synthesis, not microtubule synthesis. The correct antifungal that inhibits microtubule synthesis is griseofulvin.

choices.text: Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

For postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia of the endometrium, the recommended treatment is a total hysterectomy. This approach is taken due to the increased risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma, especially given the presence of atypia and the patient's postmenopausal status.

 

  • Simple Hysterectomy: This involves the surgical removal of the uterus and is considered the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia to prevent the progression to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a progestogen treatment used primarily for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, especially in women who desire to preserve fertility. It is not the ideal treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is used for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and as a conservative treatment for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, it is not the treatment of choice for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is typically reserved for more advanced or inoperable endometrial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units as single dose
Benzathine penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks.

 

Late cardiovascular syphilis is a form of tertiary syphilis that typically requires intensive antibiotic treatment to effectively manage the disease. The recommended regimen for treating this condition involves the administration of Benzathine penicillin G at a dose of 2.4 million units administered intramuscularly once a week for a total of three weeks. This regimen is effective because it maintains a therapeutic level of penicillin in the blood over a prolonged period, which is necessary for eradicating the persistent Treponema pallidum bacteria responsible for syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry

  • Two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially.
  • The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, a single peptide can be directed into the second MS (called parent ion or precursor ion). The parent ion enters the collision cell of the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller ions. These daughter ions (product ions) are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
  • The high selectivity of MS-MS is that the parent ion mass and daughter ion mass are used for characterization.
  • The applications of MS-MS include:
    • Identification and quantification of proteins
    • Drug screening
    • Pesticides
    • Pollutants
    • Screening of inborn errors of metabolism, especially organic acidurias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Function: Used for detecting specific proteins in a sample using antibody binding.
  • Limitation: Not suitable for broad metabolic disorder screening; used for protein analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction):

  • Function: Amplifies DNA sequences for genetic analysis.
  • Limitation: Highly specific for known genetic mutations; not suitable for comprehensive metabolic screening.

 

Option D. Gel electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates molecules (DNA, RNA, proteins) based on size and charge.
  • Limitation: Not specific or sensitive enough for broad metabolic disorder screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of fall 1 year back with parietal bone fracture, has now presented with a painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growing fracture

 

The likely diagnosis is a growing fracture, also known as a traumatic leptomeningeal cyst or encephalocele. This condition occurs when a skull fracture, particularly one associated with a dural tear, fails to heal properly. The enlargement of the fracture site may be due to the herniation of brain tissue, dilated ventricles, or the formation of a leptomeningeal cyst.

 

Clinical features of a growing fracture:

 

  • It typically occurs in children younger than 3 years old.
  • The condition is usually detected within a year of the initial head injury.
  • It presents as a localized swelling or palpable skull defect that tends to increase in size.
  • If not detected early, it can present later with symptoms such as headaches, seizures, or neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growing scalp hematoma: This condition would typically be associated with a history of jaundice and falling hemoglobin levels, which are not described in this case.

 

Option C. Subdural hygroma: Common presentations include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. These symptoms are not consistent with the presentation described in this question.

 

Option D. Chronic abscess: A chronic abscess usually presents with a long history of fever and signs of sepsis, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


A growing fracture is a rare but serious condition in young children, often presenting as a growing swelling over a skull fracture site within a year of the initial injury. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term complications.

choices.text: Nothing, since CT was normal
Start on aspirin + clopidogrel
Advice BP control

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT shows dense MCA sign. What would be your next step? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

The patient's presentation of acute left-sided facial paralysis and weakness, alongside the finding of a dense MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) sign on a CT scan, indicates an acute ischemic stroke. The dense MCA sign is a radiologic indicator of a thrombus or embolus in the MCA, which is one of the most common sites for cerebral infarctions.

 

Given that the symptoms began only 1 hour ago and the CT has confirmed the location of the occlusion without showing any signs of hemorrhage or extensive infarction (which would contraindicate thrombolysis), intravenous thrombolysis is the most appropriate intervention. This treatment is aimed at dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nothing, since CT was normal: Incorrect because the CT was not normal; it showed a dense MCA sign, indicating an acute stroke.

 

Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: This would generally be considered in secondary prevention after the acute management phase of ischemic stroke, or if the patient was not a candidate for thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Advice BP control: While controlling blood pressure is important, it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient showing signs of acute ischemic stroke with a window for thrombolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute ischemic stroke with clear indications, intravenous thrombolysis should be administered as soon as possible within the therapeutic window to improve outcomes. Immediate evaluation and management are critical to maximize recovery and minimize long-term disability.

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

 

The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5-10 mg/kg once).

 

H. nana egg is colorless, almost transparent, oval, non-bile stained, 30–50 µm (micrometers) in diameter, has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have a 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells.

 

Shell consists of two distinct membranes; inner membrane has two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is used to treat infections caused by various nematodes and ectoparasites but is not effective against cestodes like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option C. Albendazole: Albendazole is an effective treatment for various helminth infections, including some cestodes, but praziquantel is specifically preferred for Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option D. Diethylcarbamazine: Diethylcarbamazine is used primarily for treating filarial infections, not cestode infections like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Educational Objective

 

Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text: t(11,22) is best diagnosed by: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FISH

 

t(11,22) can be best detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. As part of the Human Genome Project, large libraries of bacterial artificial chromosomes that span the entire human genome were created. The human DNA insert in these clones is on the order of 100,000–200,000 base pairs, which defines the limit of resolution of FISH for identifying chromosomal changes. These DNA clones are labeled with fluorescent dyes and applied to metaphase spreads or interphase nuclei. The probe hybridizes to its homologous genomic sequence and thus labels a specific chromosomal region that can be visualized under a fluorescent microscope. The ability of FISH to circumvent the need for dividing cells is invaluable when a rapid diagnosis is warranted (e.g., when deciding to treat a patient with acute myeloid leukemia with retinoic acid, which is only effective in a particular subtype with a chromosomal translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor gene).

 

FISH can be performed on prenatal samples (e.g., cells obtained by amniocentesis, chorionic villus biopsy, or umbilical cord blood), peripheral blood lymphocytes, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even archival tissue sections. FISH has been used for detection of numeric abnormalities of chromosomes (aneuploidy); for the demonstration of subtle microdeletions or complex translocations not detectable by routine karyotyping; for analysis of gene amplification (e.g., HER2/NEU in breast cancer or N-MYC amplification in neuroblastomas); and for mapping newly isolated genes of interest to their chromosomal loci.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conventional karyotyping: Although conventional karyotyping can detect chromosomal translocations, it is less sensitive and slower than FISH, particularly for small or complex translocations.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: This procedure is used to obtain a sample for analysis, but it is not a diagnostic test in itself for specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Option D. Next generation sequencing (NGS): NGS is a powerful tool for sequencing entire genomes, but it is not typically the first choice for detecting specific chromosomal translocations like t(11;22).

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is the preferred method for detecting the t(11;22) translocation, due to its ability to precisely identify specific chromosomal abnormalities in various sample types.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 340-341​​​​​​

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma vulva

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is particularly useful in the management of vulval carcinomas among gynecological malignancies. The technique helps in determining the extent of lymph node involvement and thereby reduces unnecessary lymph node dissections and their associated complications, such as lymphedema. Sentinel lymph node biopsy can effectively identify the first lymph node (sentinel node) that drains the primary tumor, which is likely to be the first site of metastasis.

 

  • Lymphatic Mapping and Sentinel Node Biopsy:
    • Intraoperative Injection: Intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor to map lymphatic drainage.
    • Radioactive Tracer: Labeling tissues with a radioactive tracer and localizing with a hand-held detector.
    • Lymphoscintigraphy: This imaging technique has a 100% detection rate for sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Utility in Other Malignancies:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Penile carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma vagina: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is less commonly used in vaginal cancer compared to vulvar cancer.

 

Option C. Carcinoma cervix: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be used, it is more established and routinely applied in vulvar cancer.

 

Option D. Carcinoma endometrium: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is also useful but not as prominently used as in vulvar carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulvar carcinoma among gynecological malignancies to reduce unnecessary lymph node dissection and its complications.

 

Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

 

The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl's eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.

 

CMV is a -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

 

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: This does not present with the characteristic owl's eye appearance seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. Cryptococcal pneumonia: Cryptococcosis is a fungal infection that can affect the lungs but typically presents with encapsulated yeast forms, not the cytomegalic cells characteristic of CMV.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: TB typically presents with granulomas and caseating necrosis rather than the cytomegalic changes seen in CMV pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of owl's eye intranuclear inclusions in pneumocytes on lung biopsy, especially in an immunocompromised patient, is strongly suggestive of CMV-associated organizing pneumonia.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 639-640

questions.text: Identify the person to whom the First-hand knowledge rule is applicable? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common witness

 

The first-hand knowledge rule applies to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts directly observed by them. This rule ensures that the testimony provided is based on direct observation and personal experience rather than hearsay or second-hand information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Handwriting expert: An expert witness who provides testimony based on specialized knowledge or expertise, rather than direct personal observation of the facts in question.

 

Option C. Doctor: A medical professional who may provide expert testimony based on their medical expertise, rather than direct observation of the facts in question.

 

Option D. A hostile witness is a witness who appears to be refusing to fully testify in support of the person who called them or testifies in a way that significantly differs from their pre-trial.

 

Note : An expert witness is a person with extensive experience or knowledge in a specific field or discipline beyond that expected from a layperson. The expert witness's duty is to apply their expertise to give a professional opinion to the tribunal or court on particular matters in dispute. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-hand knowledge rule ensures that the testimony provided by a common witness is based on direct observation and personal experience, thereby maintaining the integrity and reliability of the evidence presented in court.

choices.text: Acute myeloid leukemia with RUNX1 mutation

questions.text: All leukemias come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid tumours except: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B-lymphoblastic leukemia/ lymphoma with hypodiploidy

 

It is not a provisional entity under WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

 

Leukemias that come under provisional entity in WHO 2016 classification of hematolymphoid are:

 

  1. Myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with PCM1-JAK2
  2. Refractory cytopenia of childhood
  3. AML with BCR-ABL1
  4. AML with mutated RUNX1 (Option C)
  5. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, BCR-ABL1–like
  6. B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with iAMP21
  7. Early T-cell precursor lymphoblastic leukemia
  8. Natural killer (NK) cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (Option A)
  9. Splenic B-cell lymphoma/leukemia, unclassifiable (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO 2016 classification introduced several provisional entities in hematolymphoid neoplasms, which are conditions that are newly recognized or still under study for their clinical significance.

 

B-lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with hypodiploidy is not a provisional entity under the WHO 2016 Classification of Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Tumors.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickets

 

The X-ray shows bow legs or genu varum, which is most commonly seen in rickets. Rickets is a bone mineralization disorder that primarily affects children with open growth plates, resulting from a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. This deficiency leads to improper bone mineralization and structural deformities, especially in weight-bearing bones such as the legs.

 

Common radiological features of rickets include:

 

  • Loss of the provisional zone of calcification (the earliest sign)
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of the growth plate
  • Cupping and fraying of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of the diaphysis

 

In toddlers, genu varum is one of the most common initial signs of rickets. Other clinical features, such as frontal bossing, rachitic rosary, and delayed closure of fontanelles, may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skeletal dysplasia: Skeletal dysplasia refers to a group of disorders affecting bone growth and development, but it does not typically present with the classical features of rickets.

 

Option C. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C and primarily affects collagen formation, leading to bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and bone pain, but it is not associated with the characteristic bowing of the legs seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Blount disease: Blount disease is a growth disorder of the tibia (shinbone) causing it to angle inward, but it typically affects older children and adolescents and has a different radiographic appearance than rickets.

 

Educational Objective:


Rickets is the most common cause of bone deformities like genu varum in children. It results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, leading to improper bone development, particularly in areas with rapid growth like the knees and wrists.

questions.text: You are overseeing the arrival of vaccines at a remote clinic. To ensure the vaccines have maintained their potency during transit, which tool would you use? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaccine vial monitor

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour or square is darker, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. e-VIN: e-VIN (Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network) tracks the stock status and temperature of vaccine inventories via the internet, but it does not assess the viability of individual vaccine vials upon arrival.

 

Option B. Freeze indicator: Freeze indicator detects exposure to freezing temperatures, which can damage vaccines, but it does not indicate heat exposure.

 

Option D. Fridge indicator: Fridge indicator monitors the temperature inside a refrigerator, ensuring it remains within a safe range but does not provide specific information about the exposure of individual vaccine vials during transport.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger
Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

 

Remember: In general, most features are larger and more prominent in males. However, there are three features which are exceptionally larger or more prominent in females. Just remember these:

 

  • Frontal Eminence is more prominent in females 
  • Parietal Eminence is more prominent in females
  • Orbits are larger in females

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larger teeth: Incorrect. Male skulls typically have larger teeth compared to females.

 

Option B. Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger: Incorrect. These sinuses are generally larger in males.

 

Option D. Supratympanic crest is present: Incorrect. This feature is more commonly found in male skulls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

 

Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.

 

Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.

 

Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.

 

Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

 

CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

 

  • Cauda equina syndrome results from compression (squeezing) of the cauda equina – the sac of nerves and nerve roots at the base and just below the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal.
  • It is a rare but serious disorder, and a medical emergency.
  • The nerves of the cauda equina provide motor and sensory function to the legs and the bladder.
  • Compression of these nerves can interrupt their function, and the effects can be severe.
  • Causes:
    • Lumbar disc herniation (most common)
    • Trauma
    • Spinal tumor
    • Spinal stenosis
    • Infection
    • Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe low back pain
    • Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence
    • Bowel incontinence
    • Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs
    • Loss of motor function in legs
    • Loss or reduction of reflexes
    • Saddle anesthesia (inability to feel anything in the body areas that would sit on a saddle)
  • Investigations:
    • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging: The best method of imaging the spinal cord, nerve roots, intervertebral discs, and ligaments. Since these scans can detect damage or disease of soft tissue, MRIs are valuable in diagnosing the cause of cauda equina syndrome.
    • Myelogram: Procedure that involves injecting a liquid dye into the spinal column. These X-ray and CT images [usually performed with a computerized tomography (CT) scan] can show pressure on the cauda equina from herniated discs and other conditions.
  • Treatment:
    • Cauda equina syndrome is a potential surgical emergency and may require timely decompression surgery to reduce/remove the pressure on the nerve(s).
    • Undergoing early surgery seems to offer the best chance for improvement of sensory and muscle function as well as bowel and bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest symptom (1st symptom). Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for anterior elements is more significant as disease involves the vertebral body (paradiscal) anteriorly. Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier).

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Elderly with bone pains, increased ESR and hypercalcemia is multiple myeloma till proved otherwise. Bone pain is the most common complaint for patients with multiple myeloma. In contrast to most bone tumors, other systemic problems, such as weakness, weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, hypercalcemia, or renal failure, frequently are present at the time of diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Symptoms usually are of short duration because of the aggressive nature of the disease. Pathological fractures are relatively common. The spine is the most common location followed by the ribs and pelvis.

 

Option D. Bone metastasis. The common symptoms include bone pain (frequent symptom), gradual in onset and described as a dull, boring pain that is worse at night. Bone metastases causing nerve root compression can present as radicular pain different from mechanical pain. As the vertebra is the most common site of metastasis, a significant complication includes spinal cord compression, which is an oncologic emergency. Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs either through pathological vertebral collapse or direct epidural extension. Patients may present initially with back pain. Limb weakness is the second most common symptom. Sensory symptoms include paresthesia and numbness at and below the level of cord compression. Autonomic dysfunction, including bowel and bladder incontinence and impotence, is typically a late presentation. In malignancy, hypercalcemia can be multifactorial and confers a poor prognosis overall. Osteolytic bone metastases are associated with 10-30% of the cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy due to enhanced osteoclastic bone resorption. Symptoms include nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, and mental status changes. Bone metastases cause bone destruction, increasing the risk for atraumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased number of theca lutein cysts

 

Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that arises from trophoblastic tissue following a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, abortion, or normal pregnancy. Indicators of choriocarcinoma include:

 

  • Persistently enlarged uterus: Indicates continued trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Plateau of high serum hCG: Persistent high levels of hCG after treatment suggest ongoing trophoblastic disease.
  • Sub-urethral nodule: A rare but specific sign of metastatic choriocarcinoma.

 

The presence of theca lutein cysts alone is not a specific indicator of choriocarcinoma, though these cysts can persist in cases of GTN. The increased number of theca lutein cysts is associated with molar pregnancies and persistent GTN but not specifically indicative of choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistently enlarged uterus: This is a common finding in choriocarcinoma due to persistent trophoblastic tissue.

 

Option C. Plateau of high serum hCG: This is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma as it indicates continued activity of the trophoblastic cells.

 

Option D. Sub-urethral nodule: This can be a sign of metastasis from choriocarcinoma. Indicates metastasis of choriocarcinoma forming a firm palpable mass beneath urethral nodule

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indicators of choriocarcinoma include persistently enlarged uterus, plateau of high serum hCG, and sub-urethral nodules, but not an increased number of theca lutein cysts alone.

 

Ref: Page no 361, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

  • One of the key elements of the National Rural Health Mission is the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition committee (VHSNC).
  • The committee has been formed to take collective actions on issues related to health and its social determinants at the village level.
  • They are particularly envisaged as being central to ‘local level community action’ under NRHM, which would develop to support the process of Decentralized Health Planning.
  • Thus VHSNC is envisaged to take leadership in providing a platform for improving health awareness and access of community for health services, address specific local needs and serve as a mechanism for community based planning and monitoring.
  • The committee is formed at the revenue village level and it should act as a sub-committee of the Gram Panchayat.
  • It should have a minimum of 15 members which should comprise of elected member of the Panchayat who shall lead the committee, all those working for health and health related services should participate, community members/ beneficiaries and representation from all community sub-groups especially the vulnerable sections and hamlets/ habitations. ASHA residing in the village shall be the member secretary and convener of the committee.

 

 ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

 

  • Create awareness about nutritional issues and significance of nutrition as an important determinant of health.
  • Carry out survey on nutritional status and nutritional deficiencies in the village especially among women and children.
  • Identify locally available food stuffs of high nutrient value as well as disseminate and promote best practices (traditional wisdom) congruent with local culture, capabilities and physical environment through a process of community consultation.
  • Inclusion of Nutritional needs in the Village Health Plan – The committee will do an in-depth analysis of causes of malnutrition at the community and household levels, by involving the ANM, AWW, ASHA and ICDS Supervisors.
  • Monitoring and Supervision of Village Health and Nutrition Day to ensure that it is organized every month in the village with the active participation of the whole village.
  • Facilitate early detection of malnourished children in the community; tie up referral to the nearest Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC) as well as follow up for sustained outcome.
  • Supervise the functioning of Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village and facilitate its working in improving nutritional status of women and children.
  • Act as a grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee and Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee generally refer to broader terms, but they do not specifically target the integrated approach of the VHSNC.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti (Patient Welfare Committee) / Hospital Management Committee is a simple yet effective management structure. This committee, a registered society, acts as a group of trustees for the hospitals to manage the affairs of the hospital. It consists of members from local Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs, local elected representatives and officials from Government sector who are responsible for proper functioning and management of the hospital / Community Health Centre / FRUs. RKS / HMS is free to prescribe, generate and use the funds with it as per its best judgement for smooth functioning and maintaining the quality of services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC plays a crucial role in the grassroots-level health planning and implementation in rural India, ensuring that health initiatives are tailored to the specific needs and conditions of the community.
  • It is a vital part of the health ecosystem, facilitating a comprehensive approach to public health management in rural settings.

questions.text: Solvent/Detergent (SD) plasma destroys lipid-enveloped viruses. So, on SD plasma transfusion, which of the following infection is likely to occur? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process used for plasma can safely inactivate all lipid-enveloped virus. HAV is a non-enveloped virus, and hence it's not affected by solvent/detergent (SD) plasma.

 

Hepatitis B, C, and HIV are enveloped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV): HIV is an enveloped virus. The SD process effectively inactivates HIV by disrupting its lipid envelope, making it non-infectious.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): HBV is also an enveloped virus. The SD process disrupts the lipid envelope of HBV, rendering it non-infectious.

 

Option D. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV): HCV is another enveloped virus. The SD process targets and inactivates HCV by disrupting its lipid envelope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The solvent/detergent (SD) process inactivates lipid-enveloped viruses such as HIV, HBV, and HCV. However, it does not inactivate non-enveloped viruses like Hepatitis A Virus (HAV), making HAV infections a potential risk during SD plasma transfusion.

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asbestosis

 

This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • Non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • Presence of characteristic asbestos bodies - asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma, a rare and aggressive cancer of the pleura.

 

 

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell – shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silicosis: Another type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust, but it does not produce asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: An infectious disease primarily caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, characterized by granulomas and caseating necrosis, not by the presence of asbestos bodies.

 

Option D. Mesothelioma: While asbestos exposure is a risk factor for mesothelioma, the histological appearance in this case is more indicative of asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is identified by the presence of characteristic asbestos bodies within the lung tissue, which are asbestos fibers coated with glycoproteins and hemosiderin, and it is commonly associated with asbestos exposure in occupational settings.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1309

questions.text: While working at a rural health sub-centre, you and a medical intern are analyzing annual infant registration metrics. The intern inquires about the expected annual infant registration rate when a health worker is actively on duty at the sub center. What is the best representation of this rate? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 150

 

Each year, a total of 150 infants should be enrolled at a sub-centre.

 

Annual infant population = Total population × % infants in population or expected birth rate

 

The infant population percentage, or the anticipated birth rate, ought to be derived from local data. In cases where a specific local percentage is not accessible, it is approximated at 3% of the overall population.

 

Total population in a sub centre = 5000.

 

Here, annual infant population = 5000 × 3/100 = 150

 

Total population catered by a Sub centre = 5000

 

Crude birth rate (CBR) India = 19 per 1000 Mid-year population (SRS 2016)

 

So, estimated number of births in a year = 19/1000 ×5000 = 95 births per year

 

  • Also, current Infant mortality rate (IMR) India = 28 per 1000 Live births
  • So, Expected number of infant deaths in a year in that population = 28/1000 × 95 = 2.7 deaths
  • So, total number of expected alive infants = 95 – 2.7 = 92 Infants approximately

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a rural health sub-centre, the expected annual infant registration rate effectively captures both the births and adjustments for infant mortality.
  • The number 150 serves as a practical target for ensuring all newborns are accounted for within the community health system.
  • This figure supports proactive health planning and resource allocation, emphasizing the importance of accurate and timely health data registration.

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding by spoon


Feeding with a spoon is a social milestone that typically develops around 18 months of age. If a child is unable to feed themselves with a spoon by 24 months, it can be considered a developmental delay. By the age of 3 years, most children should have well-established self-feeding skills, including the ability to hold and use a spoon effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one leg: This milestone typically develops around 4 years of age. It would not be considered a delay if a 3-year-old is unable to hop on one leg.

 

Option B. Drawing a square: Drawing a square is a fine motor skill that generally develops around 4 and a half years of age, so its absence at 3 years old is not considered a delay.

 

Option D. Passing a ball to someone: This social and motor skill usually develops around 4 years of age. Therefore, a 3-year-old not being able to pass a ball would not be considered delayed.

 

Educational Objective:


The absence of feeding with a spoon by 24 months can indicate a developmental delay in social and motor skills in a child.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash
From onset of rash to 5 days after rash
From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

questions.text: In a busy OPD at a District hospital, you are evaluating a 5-year-old boy who presents with fever, generalized malaise, and a distinctive rash. The child's clinical presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The mother, anxious about the contagious nature of the disease and the risk it poses to her other kids and family members, inquires about the recommended period of isolation for her infected child. What would be your most appropriate recommendation for the duration of isolation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

 

  • Patient should be advised to stay in isolation from onset of catarrhal stage to 3rd/4th day of rash.
  • Isolation is the separation for the period of communicability, of infected persons from others in such places/conditions as to prevent/limit transmission to those susceptible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage II

 

In the given case can be classified as T2N0M0 as per AJCC 2002 as the size of the lesion is between 2-4 cm (T2) with no nodal (N0) or distant metastasis (M0) and that will come under Stage II disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I: This stage would be applicable for T1 tumors, which are 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, and does not fit the description of the lesion presented.

 

Option C. Stage III: This stage would involve either T3 tumors, which are greater than 4 cm, or any T1-T3 tumors with N1 lymph node involvement, neither of which applies to this case.

 

Option D. Stage IV: This stage is reserved for more advanced disease involving T4 tumors, any tumor with N2 or N3 lymph node involvement, or distant metastasis (M1), which are not applicable in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 256

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy


The clinical presentation described is consistent with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is characterized by myoclonic jerks, which are sudden, brief, involuntary muscle contractions typically involving both arms. These jerks are most frequent in the morning, often leading to the dropping of objects, as described in this case. The patient maintains consciousness during these episodes, which is typical for JME.

 

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

 

  • Myoclonic jerks: The hallmark seizure type in JME, often occurring shortly after waking up in the morning.
  • Maintained consciousness: The patient remains aware during the myoclonic jerks.
  • Triggers: Seizures can be triggered by stimuli such as sleep deprivation, stress, and photic stimulation (e.g., flashing lights).
  • Genetics: A mutation in the GABRA1 gene is associated with JME.
  • Treatment: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice.
  • Prognosis: Generally good with appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical absence: Absence seizures are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness without motor symptoms like dropping objects. Atypical absences last longer than typical ones and have slower onset and resolution.

 

Option C. Choreo-athetoid epilepsy: This condition involves involuntary irregular movements of the face, head, trunk, and extremities, which does not align with the symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Centrotemporal spikes: Benign Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), also known as Rolandic epilepsy, involves brief stereotypical partial seizures, typically with facial and oropharyngeal involvement, not consistent with the symptomatology in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) is characterized by myoclonic jerks, typically occurring in the morning, with preserved consciousness and a good response to sodium valproate.

questions.text: Which of the following is high-molecular weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to integrins? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibronectin

 

Fibronectin is a high-molecular weight (~500-~600 kDa) glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins called integrins.

 

Integrins are cell surface receptors that play a crucial role in connecting cells to their extracellular environment, including other cells and the extracellular matrix (ECM). Integrins can connect with several types of molecules and proteins, including:

 

  1. Extracellular Matrix (ECM) Proteins: Integrins can bind to various components of the ECM, such as fibronectin, laminin, collagen, and vitronectin. These interactions allow cells to anchor to the ECM and provide structural support.
  2. Cell Adhesion Molecules: Integrins can connect with other cell adhesion molecules on neighbouring cells, promoting cell-cell interactions and the formation of multicellular structures. Examples of cell adhesion molecules include cadherins, selectins, and immunoglobulin superfamily proteins.
  3. Signalling Proteins: Integrins can also associate with intracellular signalling proteins, such as focal adhesion kinases (FAK), Src family kinases, and various adapter proteins. These interactions transmit signals from the ECM to the cell's interior, influencing cellular processes like cell growth, migration, and differentiation.
  4. Blood Clotting Factors: In platelets, integrins can bind to fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor, contributing to platelet aggregation and blood clot formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cadherin: Involved in calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion.

 

Option B. Vitronectin: Also a part of the extracellular matrix but known for its role in serum spreading factor and in the promotion of cell adhesion and spreading.

 

Option D. Selectin: Plays a role in cell adhesion during the immune response, particularly in the binding of white blood cells to the endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibronectin is a key component of the extracellular matrix that interacts with cell surface integrins to mediate various cellular processes including adhesion, migration, and tissue repair.

choices.text: Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Lower -CG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP
Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening for Down syndrome? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated B-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevated B-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct as PAPP-A is not part of the quadruple test and it typically decreases in Down syndrome.

 

Option C. Lower B-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Lower B-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP: This combination is not correct for Down syndrome. β hCG and Inhibin A are elevated in Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), the quadruple test shows elevated β hCG and Inhibin A, and decreased AFP and uE3.

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

A variety of hydrogen peroxide gas-based processes that use plasma as part of the sterilization process are known as "plasma sterilization."

 

The sterilization chamber is evacuated and hydrogen peroxide solution is injected from a cassette and is vaporized in the sterilization chamber to a concentration of 6 mg/l. The hydrogen peroxide vapor diffuses through the chamber (50 minutes), exposes all surfaces of the load to the sterilant, and initiates the inactivation of microorganisms. An electrical field created by a radio frequency is applied to the chamber to create a gas plasma. Microbicidal free radicals (e.g., hydroxyl and hydroperoxyl) are generated in the plasma. The excess gas is removed and in the final stage (i.e., vent) of the process the sterilization chamber is returned to atmospheric pressure by introduction of high-efficiency filtered air. The by-products of the cycle (e.g., water vapor, oxygen) are nontoxic and eliminate the need for aeration.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethylene oxide: Ethylene oxide is a gas used for sterilization, particularly for items that cannot withstand high temperatures. It is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are used for radiation sterilization, a different method that utilizes high-energy photons to sterilize equipment. They are not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option D. UV rays: UV rays are used for surface sterilization and disinfection. They are not part of the plasma sterilization process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma sterilization makes use of hydrogen peroxide vapor, which is activated into a plasma state by an electrical field, generating microbicidal free radicals that effectively inactivate microorganisms. This method is efficient and leaves nontoxic by-products, making it suitable for sterilizing sensitive medical and laboratory equipment.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yogurt

 

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance among the options listed. This is because yogurt contains live bacteria, specifically lactobacilli, which help to break down lactose. This fermentation process reduces the lactose content significantly, making yogurt easier to digest for individuals with lactase deficiency. Additionally, these bacteria can contribute to the production of some lactase enzyme, aiding in the digestion of any remaining lactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skimmed Milk: Contains nearly the same amount of lactose as regular milk, just with less fat. It is likely to cause symptoms in someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option B. Condensed Milk: Even higher in lactose because it is milk that has been concentrated by removing water. High lactose content makes it more likely to cause intolerance symptoms.

 

Option C. Ice-cream: Typically high in lactose because it is made from cream and milk, both of which are high in lactose. Ice cream can also contain mix-ins and flavorings that increase the lactose content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yogurt contains lactobacillus, that helps in lactase production and also low lactose levels.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastroenterology/Diarrhea/chap 471

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of doom? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iliopubic tract

 

Iliopubic tract does not form a boundary of the triangle of doom.

 

The Iliopubic tract is not a boundary of the Triangle of Doom. It is not directly associated with this anatomical region. It forms the lateral boundary of triangle of pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vas deferens: It runs medially and is considered one of the key landmarks in this anatomical region.

 

Option B. Peritoneal Reflection: It forms the inferior boundary of this anatomical triangle.

 

Option D. Spermatic vessels: The spermatic vessels are one of the boundaries of the Triangle of Doom. They are located laterally and are an important landmark in this anatomical triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of doom is bounded-

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

Apex is oriented superiorly at the internal ring

 

The contents of the space are-

 

  • External iliac vessels

 

Note: Staples must be avoided in this region during hernia repair due to the risk of injury to the vessels which might cause severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Broca's area

 

Broca's area (areas 44, 45) in this patient is damaged. This is located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, usually in the dominant hemisphere (the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals).

 

Function: Broca’s area is critical for speech production and grammar processing. Damage to Broca's area results in expressive or non-fluent aphasia. Patients typically understand spoken language and know what they want to say but struggle to form words or construct sentences. Their speech might be slow, with a struggle to find the right words, and they might omit small connecting words like "is" or "the."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's Area:

 

  • Location: This area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in about 95% of right-handed individuals and 70% of left-handed individuals.
  • Function: Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension. Damage to this area results in receptive aphasia. Patients can produce speech, but it often lacks meaning, and they have difficulty understanding spoken or written language. Their speech might be fluent, but it's usually nonsensical or includes made-up words.

 

Option C. Heschl's Gyrus:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary auditory cortex within the Sylvian fissure in the temporal lobe.
  • Function: Heschl's gyrus is responsible for primary auditory processing, meaning it processes incoming auditory information. Damage to this area might impair the ability to perceive sounds.

 

Option D. Striate Area:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
  • Function: The striate area (or V1) is the primary processing center for visual information. Damage to this area can lead to blindness or partial visual field deficits depending on the extent and location of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the device given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoport

 

The image shows a chemoport. Chemoports are implantable venous access devices specifically designed to facilitate the administration of chemotherapy in patients. These devices allow for repeated access to the venous system, making them suitable for long-term use in cancer treatment. They are implanted under the skin, typically in the chest area, with the catheter inserted into large veins, commonly the internal jugular or subclavian veins. The device remains in place for 1 to 2 years or longer, depending on the treatment requirements, and is later explanted once it is no longer needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis port: A dialysis port is a device used to provide vascular access for hemodialysis. It has a different design and is intended specifically for dialysis treatments rather than chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Electro-convulsive therapy lead : This lead is used in electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) to deliver electric currents to the brain for therapeutic purposes in certain psychiatric conditions. It has no use in chemotherapy administration or venous access.

 

 

Option D. Gamma camera : A gamma camera is a diagnostic imaging device used in nuclear medicine to visualize the distribution of radioactive tracers in the body. It is not an implantable device and has no function in delivering chemotherapy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A chemoport is an implantable venous access device used for administering chemotherapy, commonly placed in large veins like the internal jugular or subclavian veins.

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb, is due to the involvement of the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN). This is a branch of the median nerve. It runs down the forearm along with the anterior interosseous artery.

 

It supplies the deep muscles of the anterior (flexor) compartment of the forearm. Specifically, it provides innervation to the flexor pollicis longus (which flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb), the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus. Injury to this nerve can lead to the inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, leading to the characteristic "pinch sign" or "OK sign" presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the ulnar nerve after it passes the flexor retinaculum in the wrist. The deep branch is mainly motor in function.

 

  • This nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles (muscles of the little finger), the ulnar two lumbricals, all the interossei (both palmar and dorsal), and adductor pollicis. It does not have any role in the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Option B. Median Nerve: This nerve originates from both the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus. It travels down the arm and forearm and goes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist.

 

  • It supplies most of the flexors in the forearm and several muscles in the hand, including the thenar muscles (muscles of the thumb). But the flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb is more specifically due to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, not the main trunk of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Posterior Interosseous Nerve: It is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve. It travels in the forearm between the superficial and deep layers of muscles.

 

  • This nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. It's not involved in flexion movements and hence, not responsible for the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexion of thumb occurs at 2 joints:

 

  1. IP joint: Flexor pollicis longs (FPL) supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve, C7 and C8).
  2. MCP joint: Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB supplied by the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Most commonly injured nerve in SCH fracture: AIN > Median > Radial > Ulnar (AMRU)

 

  • Deep branch of ulnar nerve → ulnar claw hand
  • Posterior interosseous nerve → innervates the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. Weakness or paralysis of these muscles can cause difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent post-partum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentle massage of uterus

 

AMTSL

 

Purpose: To prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a major cause of maternal death.

 

  1. Give a uterotonic drug
    • Oxytocin 10 IU IM immediately after the birth of the baby
    • This helps the uterus contract and reduce bleeding
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
    • Gently pull the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to help deliver the placenta
    • Only if trained and placenta is ready to come
  3. Intermittent uterine tone assessment

 

Delayed cord clamping

 

  • Wait 1–3 minutes before clamping the umbilical cord
  • Improves baby’s iron stores and reduces anemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery: This is a critical step in AMTSL to prevent PPH by promoting uterine contractions.

 

Option B. Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord: Delayed cord clamping (after 1 to 3 minutes) is recommended for all births to enhance neonatal outcomes

 

Option D. Controlled cord traction: This is a part of AMTSL to aid in the delivery of the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor includes the administration of a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and assessing uterine tone rather than sustained uterine massage for all women who have received a uterotonic.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/120082/WHO_RHR_14.20_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of immunization for her newborn. She is particularly interested in understanding the BCG vaccine's benefits, as she has heard conflicting opinions from friends and family. Based on current evidence and guidelines, which of the following best describes the primary protective effects of the BCG vaccine in the context of tuberculosis (TB)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CNS and disseminated TB 

 

  • BCG vaccine provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB.

 

BCG Vaccine

 

  • LIVE, Attenuated, Lyophilised vaccine
  • Reconstituent – NORMAL SALINE
  • Strain DANISH–1331 (VIA M. BOVIS, 239 SC FOR 13 YR)
  • Dose 0.05 (upto 28 days, then 0.1 ml) ID, just above insertion of left deltoid
  • Efficacy 0-80% (MEDIAN-50%)
  • Dose at birth, 1 TU in 0.1 ml
  • 20 years protection {No protection against pulmonary TB}

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.

 

Option B. Lentiform Nucleus: Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.

 

Option D. Red Nucleus: Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus.
