The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) recognizes? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipids without MHC proteins

 

  • A small population of mature T cells expresses a type of TCR composed of γ and δ polypeptide chains. The γδ TCR recognizes peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. γδ T cells tend to aggregate at epithelial surfaces, such as the skin and mucosa of the gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts, suggesting that these cells are sentinels that protect against microbes that try to enter through epithelia
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peptides with MHC proteins: This is characteristic of αβ TCRs, not γδ TCRs.

 

Option C. CD20: CD20 is a B cell marker, not a target recognized by T cell receptors.

 

Option D. CD3: CD3 is a signaling molecule associated with the T cell receptor complex but is not a specific target recognized by the TCR itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) are unique in that they can recognize lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation, distinguishing them from the more common αβ T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C-Hypothalamus

 

The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus. The structure marked as C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus Callosum: It's a large white matter structure found deep within the brain, lying superiorly to the thalamus and under the cortex. It connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

 

  • The primary purpose of the corpus callosum is to integrate motor, sensory, and cognitive performances between the cerebral cortex on one side of the brain to the same region on the other side. Essentially, it allows for communication between the two hemispheres of the brain.

 

Option C. Pituitary Gland: It is a pea-sized structure that's located at the base of the brain, right below the hypothalamus.

 

  • Often referred to as the "master gland," the pituitary gland secretes hormones that control several other endocrine glands. It has an anterior and posterior portion, each releasing specific hormones. These hormones regulate various physiological processes, including growth, reproductive cycles, and stress response.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Located at the ventral part of the brain, below the occipital lobes and posterior to the brainstem.

 

  • The cerebellum is primarily responsible for coordination and fine-tuning of motor movements. It also plays roles in posture and balance, and there is increasing evidence that it's involved in cognitive functions and emotion regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothalamus is situated at the base of the brain, just below the thalamus and right above the pituitary gland. This plays a crucial role in many important functions, including releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite, managing of sexual behavior, and responding to the feeling of being full (eating).

choices.text: HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV, Anti HEV
HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HDV, Anti-HEV, Anti-HCV

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and RUQ pain. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to eating food. On examination icterus was present. What investigations would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)


Liver function test results are given below:

 

  • Total Bilirubin 18.5
  • Direct Bilirubin 10.5   
  • SGOT/AST 723
  • SGPT/ALT 812
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV

 

Above history is suggestive of acute viral hepatitis with ALT>AST and elevated >10X times. With resolution of symptoms jaundice gradually increases and spontaneously improves.

 

Common causes of AST, ALT > 10X are Viral Hepatitis (B, A, C-rare, E-In pregnancy/Post-transplant), Toxins, Shock liver, Fulminant Wilsons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HEV testing routinely not employed

 

Option C. Hepatitis D usually causes severe disease when B+D coinfection occurs.

 

Option D. HbsAg is first test of hep B infection W/IgM HbC suggest FLARE, window period, acute infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected acute viral hepatitis with significant liver enzyme elevation and icterus, it's essential to conduct a thorough serological evaluation to determine the specific type of hepatitis virus involved. This allows for targeted management and appropriate precautions to prevent transmission.

 

Reference: Harrison/gastroenterology/Viral Hepatitis/Chap 339

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital glaucoma

 

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea, along with the image suggests a diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.

 

 

  • Diagnostic features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.
  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy
  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
      • Goniotomy: to remove obstructed tissue in the eye's drainage system.
      • Trabeculotomy: creates a drainage opening in the eye's trabecular meshwork.
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.
      • Trabeculectomy: creates a new drainage channel for aqueous humor.
      • Tube shunt implantation: involves placing a small tube in the eye to drain excess fluid.
      • Ciliary body ablative procedures: destroy the ciliary body to reduce the production of aqueous humor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma: A cancer that would show more than simple enlargement of the corneas, typically presenting with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria).

 

Option C. Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Primarily affects the endothelium of the cornea, not associated with the enlargement of the corneas or elevated IOP.

 

Option D. Megalocornea: A non-glaucomatous condition where the corneas are enlarged but without other symptoms like photophobia or increased IOP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital glaucoma is characterized by symptoms like enlarged corneas, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation due to elevated intraocular pressure from developmental anomalies in the anterior chamber angle. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through

 

The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study should be the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

 

A Gastrograffin follow-through is a radiological procedure that involves the administration of contrast material (Gastrograffin) followed by a series of X-rays to visualize the gastrointestinal tract. An alternate investigation would be CT with contrast (not given in options). In cases of recurrent bilious vomiting, it is a valuable diagnostic tool to assess for intestinal obstruction, such as malrotation or other anatomical abnormalities. It helps determine if there are any blockages or abnormalities in the intestines that may be causing the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Performing an endoscopy is generally not the first-line investigation for a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting where an obstructive GI pathology is likely.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: An ultrasound (USG) of the abdomen can provide useful information in some cases, but it may not be the most appropriate initial investigation for recurrent bilious vomiting when there is a need to evaluate the entire gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Explorative laparotomy, which involves surgery to explore the abdominal cavity, is a more invasive option and is typically considered when other diagnostic methods have failed to provide a clear diagnosis or when there is a strong suspicion of a surgical emergency. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel atresia’s present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.

 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

 

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia.

 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction

 

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is performed. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in OPD? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azithromycin

 

Decision for OPD vs Admission for CAP is assessed by CURB-65, PSI score.

 

For patients with risk factors (CKD, non-ambulator, Recent ABx, hospitalization last 3 months), macrolide + Beta-lactam /Respiratory FQ preferred.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin given only if CA-MRSA is considered.

 

Suspicion for MRSA:

 

1. Necrotizing/Cavitary pneumonia

2. Pleural based nodules

3. Post viral pneumonia

4. Treatment failure (Sx, hypoxemia, MODS @ 72 hours post admission)

5. IVDU

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone is given for IP treatment and administered I.V.

 

Option D. Streptomycin is not used in management of CAP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Azithromycin is a commonly used antibiotic for the outpatient treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to its effectiveness against a wide range of respiratory pathogens and its patient-friendly dosing schedule.

 

Reference - Harrison/Respiratory /Pneumonia/Chapter 126

choices.text: tRNA of Alanine
U6 SnRNA
mRNA for Histone

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5' capping? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) tRNA of Alanine

 

5’ capping - Eukaryotic mRNAs are all ‘capped’ at the 5′ terminus by 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate. An unusual 5’ to 5′ triphosphate bridge is seen. This happens inside the nucleus. The cap is useful in recognition of mRNA by the translating machinery and in prevention of degradation by exonucleases.

 

Poly-A Tailing at 3′ End - The 3’ terminus is polyadenylated in the nucleoplasm. This

poly-A tail may be 20 to 250 nucleotides long. This tail protects mRNA from attack by 3′ exonuclease.

 

Note: tRNA do not require capping at 5’ end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. U6 SnRNA:

  • Function: U6 snRNA is part of the spliceosome complex involved in RNA splicing.
  • Modification: U6 snRNA is not typically capped with 7-methyl guanosine but may undergo other modifications.

 

Option C. mRNA for Histone:

  • Function: Histone mRNAs are unique in that they typically do not have poly-A tails but do require 5' capping.
  • Modification: Despite lacking poly-A tails, histone mRNAs still undergo 5' capping.

 

Option D. SiRNA (Small interfering RNA):

  • Function: SiRNAs are involved in the RNA interference pathway, leading to the degradation of target mRNAs.
  • Modification: SiRNAs are typically not capped at the 5' end as they are processed from longer double-stranded RNA precursors.

 

Educational objective:

 

tRNA, including tRNA for alanine, does not require 5' capping. This modification is specific to mRNAs and some snRNAs, playing a critical role in mRNA stability and translation.

choices.text: To hold and support the specimen slide
To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen
To adjust the focus and clarity of the image

questions.text: What is the primary function of the condenser in a compound microscope? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

 

The condenser in a compound microscope is a crucial component located within or below the stage (sub-stage). Its primary function is to gather and concentrate light from the microscope's illuminator and direct it into a light cone that focuses on the specimen.

 

Condenser Function:

 

  • Light Regulation: The condenser focuses and concentrates the light onto the specimen to ensure optimal illumination, which is critical for viewing the specimen clearly.
  • Improving Image Quality: By regulating and directing the light precisely, the condenser enhances the contrast and clarity of the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To magnify the specimen image: Magnification is achieved by the objective lenses and eyepiece, not by the condenser.

 

Option B. To hold and support the specimen slide: The stage is the part of the microscope that holds and supports the specimen slide, not the condenser.

 

Option D. To adjust the focus and clarity of the image: Focus adjustment is achieved using the coarse and fine adjustment knobs, not the condenser.

 

Parts of Microscope

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

 

Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): pair of tracts that interconnect CN VI and CN III nuclei. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is responsible for coordinating horizontal eye movements. The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and travels to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). From there, an output goes to the left VI nerve nucleus, which supplies the left lateral rectus muscle, causing abduction. Another output from the left PPRF goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing the right eye to adduct.

 

If there is a lesion in the right MLF, it leads to the failure of adduction of the right eye. However, the left eye abducts normally. This is the classic presentation of INO.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th Nerve nucleus: A lesion here would result in an inability to abduct the eye on the same side, not INO.

 

Option C. Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF): A lesion here would typically affect both the initiation of gaze to the ipsilateral side and horizontal gaze coordination, leading to symptoms different from typical INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

questions.text: Size cut off for operating an abdominal aortic aneurysm is greater than? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.5 cm

 

(5.5) The threshold for surgical repair of an AAA is commonly set at 5.5 cm in diameter. This means that when the AAA reaches or exceeds 5.5 cm in size, surgical intervention is usually recommended to prevent the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AAA refers to an enlargement or ballooning of the abdominal aorta. It can be a potentially life-threatening condition if it ruptures.

 

The size of the AAA is a crucial factor in determining the need for surgical intervention. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the size of the aneurysm grows.

 

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient is considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 70 mm in diameter.

 

As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >55 mm.

 

6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic surveillance is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <55 mm in diameter.

questions.text: Toluidine blue staining is used in the Identification of which of the following cells? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mast Cell

 

Toluidine blue is the special stain for mast cells.

 

Toluidine blue (also known as tolonium chloride) is an acidophilic metachromatic dye that selectively stains acidic tissue components (sulfates, carboxylates, and phosphate radicals). Toluidine blue (TB. has an affinity for nucleic acids, and therefore binds to nuclear material of tissues with a high DNA and RNA content.

 

It also intensely stains some substances leading to a change in color. This effect known as metachromasia.

 

  • Orthochromatic Staining - structures stained blue (Lymphocytes)
  • Metachromatic Staining - structures stained dark purple from polymeric aggregates formed when binding to high concentrations of polyanions (Mast cells)

 

Toluidine blue is often used to identify mast cells by virtue of heparin (which is very polyanionic. found in their secretion granules.

 

 

Application of Toluidine Blue

 

  1. Connective tissue mucins, especially acid mucins. The tissue stains purple to red, while the background is stained blue.
  2. Mast cell granules stain purple in color due to the presence of heparin and histamine.
  3. Amyloid stain blue but under polarized light they give a bright red birefringence.
  4. Endocrine cell granules are stained purple to red.
  5. Sulfatides stain red brown or yellow. Only lipids that are sufficiently acidic to induce a metachromatic shift are stained.
  6. Corynebacterium diphtheria contains granules with polymerized inorganic polyphosphate, which stains red violet color.
  7. Helicobacter stains dark blue against a variably blue background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocyte: Lymphocytes can be stained with toluidine blue, but they show orthochromatic staining (blue), not the metachromasia that is characteristic of mast cells.

 

Option B. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are not specifically identified by toluidine blue staining.

 

Option C. Macrophage: While macrophages can be stained with various dyes, they do not exhibit the metachromasia seen in mast cells with toluidine blue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toluidine blue is primarily used to identify mast cells due to their characteristic metachromatic staining caused by the heparin in their granules.

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the incorrect pairing. The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery doesn't primarily supply the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly supplied by branches from the vertebral arteries, such as the posterior meningeal artery.
  • The meningeal branches of Internal Carotid artery supply the anterior cranial fossa 
     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the most significant arterial supply to the dura mater. After entering the skull through the foramen spinosum, it typically divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies the dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option B. Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal artery is a smaller branch that originates from the maxillary artery. It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale. This artery supplies the dura of the middle cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries arise from the ophthalmic artery (a branch of the internal carotid artery). These arteries have meningeal branches that supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the region overlying the ethmoid bone and the frontal bone's adjacent parts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Summary of Blood supply to Dura

  1. Anterior cranial fossa
    1. By ethmoidal artery which is the branch of opthalmic artery which in tern is the branch of Internal carotid artery 
    2. Middle meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  2. Middle cranial fossa
    1. Accessory meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  3. Posterior Cranial fossa
    1. Meningeal branches from the branches of the vertebral artery.
       
  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) meningeal branch supply blood to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries, which run along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull and supply the following regions.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). 

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

 

The given clinical history is suggesting a most probable diagnosis of phenylketonuria (PKU)

Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase is the cause for this disease.

 

Biochemical Abnormalities:

  1. Phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine. So, phenylalanine accumulates. Phenylalanine level in blood is elevated.
  2. So alternate minor pathways are opened. Phenylketone (phenylpyruvate), phenyllactate and phenylacetate are excreted in urine.

 

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  1. The classical PKU child is mentally retarded with an IQ of 50.
  2. Agitation, hyperactivity, tremors and convulsions are often manifested. This may be because phenylalanine interferes with neurotransmitter synthesis.
  3. The child often has hypopigmentation, explained by the inhibition of tyrosinase.
  4. Phenyl acetic acid in sweat may lead to mousy body odor.

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  1. Blood phenylalanine: Normal level is 1 mg/dL. In PKU, the level is >20 mg/dL. This may be demonstrated by chromatography. Tandem mass spectroscopy is the most reliable test; but is costly.
  2. Guthrie test is a rapid screening test - Certain strains of Bacillus subtilis need phenylalanine as an essential growth factor. Bacteria cannot grow in a medium devoid of phenylalanine. Bacterial growth is proportional to the phenylalanine content in the patient’s blood.
  3. Ferric chloride test: Urine of the patient contains phenylketones about 500–3000 mg/day. This could be detected by adding a drop of ferric chloride to the urine. A transient blue-green color is a positive test. But this is a less reliable test.
  4. DNA probes are now available to diagnose the defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase and dihydrobiopterin reductase.

 

Treatment:

  1. Early detection is very important. About 5 units of IQ are lost for each 10-week delay in starting the treatment.
  2. The treatment is to provide a diet containing low phenylalanine (10–20 mg/kg body weight per day)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme defect: True: This is the primary defect in PKU, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Option C. Phenylacetate positive in urine: True: Phenylacetate, a metabolite of phenylalanine, is found in the urine of patients with PKU.

 

Option D. Mental retardation is present: True: Without early treatment, children with PKU often suffer from severe mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKU is characterized by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels and its metabolites, which cause neurological symptoms, hypopigmentation, and a musty odor. Early detection and dietary management are crucial for preventing severe mental retardation.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. i-3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2 

 

i. Mummification - Image 3. It is a method of embalming the dead body. It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air.

 

ii. Adipocere - Image 4. It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids.

 

iii. Marbling - Image 1. In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

iv. Postmortem lividity - Image 2. Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis or postmortem lividity, is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mummification: Occurs in dry or warm environments, preserving the body by desiccation.
  • Adipocere: Forms in warm, humid conditions through the hydrolysis of lipids, leading to a waxy transformation of body fat.
  • Marbling: Blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks due to sulphmethemoglobin formation, appearing within 24 hours and becoming prominent by 36-48 hours.
  • Postmortem Lividity: Blood accumulates in dependent body parts due to gravity, causing discoloration from pink to dark purple.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug.

 

A misbranded drug will not produce the effect due to reasons like lesser dose, different molecules in it etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: are drugs with improper labelling, labeling from a fictitious company, with improper storage guidelines, or even partly or wholly substituted by another drug or substance.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: are drugs with unwanted substance, for example iron in Paracetamol.

 

Option C. unethical drug: The term unethical drug is not used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug that is labeled as containing a certain amount of an active ingredient but actually contains a different amount is considered misbranded. Misbranded drugs can lead to ineffective treatment and potential harm due to incorrect dosing.

choices.text: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents
It is associated with adjacent inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma membrane remains intact  

 

The plasma membrane remains intact in apoptosis.

 

Apoptosis literally means falling-off in Greek. It is a pathway of programmed cell death.

 

Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have intact plasma membrane but altered structures. Hence, they are subjected to phagocytosis without eliciting inflammation.

 

Key Features of Apoptosis:

 

  • Cell shrinkage: The cell becomes smaller in size.
  • Chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation (called pyknosis and karyorrhexis).
  • Formation of apoptotic bodies: The cell fragments into small, membrane-bound vesicles.
  • Phagocytosis without inflammation: Apoptotic bodies are recognized and engulfed by macrophages or nearby cells.
  • Plasma membrane remains intact during the entire process, preventing leakage of contents and avoiding inflammation.

 

Necrosis is an unprogrammed form of cell death that includes:

 

  • Enzymatic digestion
  • Adjacent inflammation
  • Karyolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents: This occurs in necrosis, not apoptosis.

 

Option B. Karyolysis is present: Karyolysis is a feature of necrosis, not apoptosis. In apoptosis, the nucleus fragments in an orderly manner.

 

Option D. It is associated with adjacent inflammation: Inflammation is characteristic of necrosis due to the release of cellular contents, but apoptosis avoids this through the containment of cell contents within intact membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 59

choices.text: Closure of tricuspid valve
Onset of ventricular systole
Maximal atrial filling

questions.text: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

 

The 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) represents right atrial contraction. This occurs towards the end of ventricular diastole and reflects the pressure increase within the right atrium as it contracts to push blood into the right ventricle just before the tricuspid valve closes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Closure of tricuspid valve: Incorrect, this would not be specifically represented by an 'a' wave; instead, it typically follows the 'a' wave and leads into the 'c' wave associated with right ventricular contraction.

 

Option C. Onset of ventricular systole: Incorrect, ventricular systole corresponds to the 'c' wave and the 'x' descent on JVP.

 

Option D. Maximal atrial filling: Incorrect, maximal atrial filling occurs towards the end of the 'v' wave and into the 'y' descent, which corresponds to passive ventricular filling when the tricuspid valve is open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Harrison/Cardiology/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

choices.text: Primary active transport
Secondary active transport
Any of the above

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

 

  1. Glucose enters the lumen of the small intestine.
  2. Sodium ions (Na+) are present in the lumen of the intestine.
  3. Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1) on the luminal membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose absorption:
    1. SGLT1 binds to both glucose and sodium ions.
    2. Sodium ions move down their electrochemical gradient into the enterocyte, providing energy for transport.
    3. Glucose molecules are co-transported with sodium ions into the enterocyte.
  4. Glucose enters the cytoplasm of the enterocyte.
  5. Inside the enterocyte, glucose can be used for energy or transported across the basolateral membrane.
  6. Glucose Transporter 2 (GLUT2) on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose transport out of the cell:
    1. GLUT2 allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient.
    2. Glucose diffuses across the basolateral membrane into the bloodstream.
  7. Glucose is carried away by the bloodstream to various tissues and organs for utilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Involves direct use of ATP for the movement of substances against their concentration gradient and does not apply to glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive movement of molecules along their concentration gradient through a membrane protein, applies to the exit of glucose at the basolateral side but not to its uptake at the luminal side.

 

Option D. Any of the above: Not applicable as the specific mechanism for glucose absorption is secondary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following will not commonly present as shown in the image below?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspergillus

 

The image shows a dermatophytic infection in the groin region called as Tinea cruris. Aspergillus species are not dermatophytes & are not associated with tinea infections.

 

This genus of fungi is not commonly involved in tinea infections. Aspergillus species are known to cause various diseases, primarily in the respiratory system, such as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. They are not usually responsible for superficial skin infections like the one shown in the image.

 

Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different color. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea (Dermatophytic infection).

 

 

 

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Trichophyton species infect skin, hair and nails. E.g., T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails).
  • ﻿﻿﻿Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, it infects only skin and nails (not hair).

 

Dermatophytes infect and survive only in the dead keratin layers of skin (stratum corneum), hair and nails as they are Keratinophilic.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Trichophyton species are among the most common dermatophytes associated with Tinea cruris. They infect skin, hair, and nails and are known for their role in various forms of tinea, including Tinea cruris.
  • Why it could present as shown: Trichophyton often causes ring-shaped lesions with a clear center and scaly borders, matching the typical presentation of Tinea cruris.

 

Option B. Microsporum:

 

  • Explanation: While Microsporum primarily infects the hair and skin and is less commonly associated with Tinea cruris compared to Trichophyton, it can still cause dermatophytic infections of the groin.
  • Why it could present as shown: Microsporum can cause similar clinical manifestations as Trichophyton in Tinea infections, including red, itchy, and ring-shaped rashes.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Epidermophyton floccosum specifically targets the skin and nails and is a known causative agent of Tinea cruris. This fungus does not infect the hair, differentiating it from some other dermatophytes.
  • Why it could present as shown: Similar to other dermatophytes, Epidermophyton can cause the classic ring-shaped lesions of Tinea cruris with involvement of the groin area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus species do not typically cause superficial skin infections such as tinea cruris; instead, they are more associated with respiratory system conditions. Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton are genera of fungi that commonly cause dermatophytosis like the tinea infections seen in the presented image.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.18-20

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 9th edition Page no 599

choices.text: Oxidation of Fatty acids
None of the above

questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphocreatine

 

Phosphocreatine (also called creatine phosphate) is another chemical compound that has a high-energy phosphate bond. The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run.

 

Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aerobic glycolysis: This process occurs in the mitochondria and is used for longer-duration, lower-intensity exercise. It involves the oxidation of glucose to produce ATP, but it is too slow to meet the immediate energy demands of a 100-meter dash.

 

Option C. Oxidation of Fatty acids: This is a slower process involving the breakdown of fatty acids in the mitochondria to produce ATP. It primarily supports prolonged, steady-state activities rather than short bursts of high-intensity exercise.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as phosphocreatine is the primary source of rapid ATP replenishment during short, high-intensity activities like a 100-meter dash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a 100-meter dash, the primary source of energy for rapidly replenishing ATP in skeletal muscles is the phosphagen system, utilizing phosphocreatine for short bursts of maximal muscle power lasting approximately 8 to 10 seconds.

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e., 12 microgram/ml? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 27 minutes

 

The time taken for the formation of the same amount of product is 27 minutes.

 

When the substrate concentration is much greater than the Km value, the rate of the reaction is independent of the substrate concentration i.e., it follows zero-order kinetics. In this reaction, the substrate concentration is 1000 times the Km value therefore it follows zero-order kinetics. So, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction.

 

The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. As the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd, the velocity of the reaction also becomes 1/3rd.

 

Therefore, the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled. That is, 9 × 3 = 27 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In zero-order kinetics, the reaction rate is independent of substrate concentration but directly proportional to enzyme concentration. Reducing the enzyme concentration to 1/3 increases the time taken to produce the same amount of product by a factor of 3.

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EPEC

 

Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

 

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

 

  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETEC: ETEC is known for causing watery diarrhea via enterotoxins but does not cause the attachment and effacement lesions seen with EPEC.

 

Option B. EIEC: EIEC causes invasive disease and dysentery by invading and destroying epithelial cells, but it does not cause attachment and effacement lesions.

 

Option D. EHEC: EHEC causes hemorrhagic colitis and can lead to hemolytic-uremic syndrome through the production of Shiga toxin, but it does not cause the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as EPEC does.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year gentleman was referred from outside hospital to AIIMS ER after he developed sudden onset quadriparesis. In hospital patient was treated with 3%NaCl, Oral tolvaptan. Initial metabolic panel revealed Na: 115 mEq/L, K: 2.8 mEq/L, Cl: 85 mEq/L with normal TSH, CBC, RFT, LFT.  What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?  (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Previously called central pontine myelinolysis. It occurs due to rapid correction of Chronic Hyponatremia (>8 mg/dL).

 

Timing: 2-6 days after rapid correction.

 

Rx: Irreversible. Desmopressin clamp if overcorrection in q6h Na values.  

 

Mechanism:

 

1. In Hyponatremia

 

 

2. On sudden correction:

 

 

Risk factors:

 

  1. Serum sodium ≤ 105 mEq/L
  2. Concurrent hypokalemia
  3. Chronic excess alcohol intake
  4. Acute or chronic hepatic disease
  5. Malnourishment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain infarct: Not directly suggested by the rapid onset of symptoms following electrolyte correction.

 

Option B. Brainstem injury: Could be considered but is less likely without trauma or vascular insult history.

 

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Not applicable as the condition involves the rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia should be avoided to prevent the severe neurological complications associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome. Control and monitoring of serum sodium levels are crucial during treatment.

 

Reference - Harrison/Electrolytes/Chap 53

questions.text: Cancer that least commonly spreads by lymphatic route is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive tumor that rarely spreads by the lymphatic route.

 

Mutations in sonic hedgehog pathway are associated with it.

 

Grossly, the most common pattern is a nodulo-ulcerative basal cell carcinoma in which a slow-growing small nodule undergoes central ulceration with pearly, rolled margins.

 

 

The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC. may lead to confusion with melanoma.

 

It occurs exclusively on hairy skin, the most common location (90%) being the face, usually above a line from the lobe of the ear to the corner of the mouth. The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

 

 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is primarily locally invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatic system, particularly when occurring in the skin or mucous membranes.

 

Option B. Merkel Cell Carcinoma: This is a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer that frequently metastasizes via the lymphatic system.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Melanoma is known for its high metastatic potential, often spreading through both lymphatic and hematogenous routes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a locally invasive tumor that rarely spreads via the lymphatic or hematogenous routes, distinguishing it from other more aggressive skin cancers.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a complex condition characterized by systemic activation of blood clotting, which results in the generation and deposition of fibrin, leading to microvascular thrombi in various organs and contributing to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. As a part of this process, there is widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets, which leads to a paradoxical increase in bleeding risk.

 

  • Increased fibrinogen is incorrect because in DIC, fibrinogen is typically decreased, not increased. This decrease is due to its consumption during the formation of fibrin clots throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% of patients w/DIC may have schistocytes on PS.

 

Option B. Consumption of clotting factors leads to ↑PT, aPTT. Presence of normal PT, aPTT w/schistocytes hints towards possibility of MAHA.

 

Option D. FDP are elevated due to activation of coagulation cascade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener’s syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener’s syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener’s syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics

 

The recommended duration for isolation in cases of bacterial meningitis is until 24 hours after the initiation of effective antibiotic therapy. This is crucial for preventing the spread of infections caused by organisms such as Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). After 24 hours of effective treatment, the risk of transmission significantly decreases, allowing the patient to be removed from isolation.

 

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

 

  • Standard precautions should be implemented for all patients admitted with meningitis.
  • Patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Hib meningitis should be placed on droplet precautions until they have received 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.
  • Patients with these infections should be placed in private rooms during this isolation period.
  • Hospital personnel should wear a face mask when within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Till cultures become negative: This is not a practical or recommended criterion for lifting isolation because cultures can take several days to become negative, and the patient is not typically contagious after 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option C. Till antibiotic course is complete: The full course of antibiotics may last 7-14 days, during which time isolation is not necessary after the first 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option D. Till 12 hours after admission: This is incorrect as it does not meet the standard infection control guidelines. The 24-hour mark after starting effective antibiotics is the critical time point for lifting isolation.

 

Educational Objective:


Children with bacterial meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Haemophilus influenzae should be isolated for 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic therapy to prevent transmission.

questions.text: A young female has history of a induced abortion at 11 weeks. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion and subsequent dilation and curettage (D&C) is typically due to intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome.

 

  • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C.
    • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome.
    • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.

Other options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: This would typically be associated with abnormal levels of pituitary hormones, including FSH. The normal FSH level (6 mIU/ml) suggests that pituitary function is intact.

 

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: This condition would generally present with elevated or depressed levels of FSH and other ovarian hormones. The normal FSH level suggests that ovarian function is likely normal.

 

Option C. First pregnancy: In pregnancy, FSH levels are very low (<0.1 mIU/ml). The FSH level of 6 mIU/ml makes this an unlikely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a history of spontaneous abortion and D&C is usually due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), diagnosed by hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection
Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque in X-ray images
Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray.
Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding X Rays? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Live bone is more radio-opaque than dead bone on X- Ray images.

 

Explanation:

 

On X-ray imaging, dead bones are whiter (more radio-opaque) than live bone due to absence of bone resorption activity as vascular demineralization is lost. This is known as sequestrum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest X-ray change of infection: This statement is true. The loss of definition of soft tissue planes due to swelling or fluid accumulation is often the earliest radiographic sign of infection, typically appearing within 24-48 hours after disease onset.

 

Option B. Glass pieces can be seen as radiopaque on X-ray images: This is true. Glass, especially if it contains lead, shows up as radiopaque on X-rays, making it visible.

 

Option C. Cartilage is not visualized on X-ray: This is true. Cartilage itself does not appear on X-rays because it does not absorb X-rays well; the space where cartilage is located appears radiolucent, which is often perceived as joint space.

 

Educational Objective:


On X-ray imaging, dead bone appears more radio-opaque than live bone due to the lack of resorption activity. Understanding these differences is crucial for correctly interpreting radiologic findings related to bone vitality and infection.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The image displays a displaced patellar fracture, and the treatment of choice is Tension Band Wiring.
  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using: 
    • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
    • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text: The best method to measure HbA1c is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ion exchange chromatography

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood

glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6–8 weeks.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

 

Ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on charge differences between HbA1c and other hemoglobins. It is considered as a gold standard for HbA1c analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoelectric focusing:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their isoelectric points.
  • Limitation: Not commonly used for HbA1c measurement due to complexity and lower specificity for glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography:

  • Function: Uses specific binding interactions to separate molecules.
  • Limitation: While effective in some contexts, it is not the most common method for routine HbA1c measurement.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their size and charge under an electric field.
  • Limitation: Not as specific or reliable for HbA1c measurement compared to ion-exchange HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard for measuring HbA1c due to its high accuracy and ability to separate HbA1c from other hemoglobin variants based on charge differences.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the Infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation would you do? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum calcium

 

In infants born to diabetic mothers, it is essential to assess the serum calcium level to rule out hypocalcemia. Infants of diabetic mothers are predisposed to conditions like hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

 

  • Hypocalcemia is defined as a total serum calcium level below 8 mg/dL in term infants and below 7 mg/dL in preterm infants. This condition often occurs due to lower levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in infants of diabetic mothers. In utero, the higher levels of maternal serum ionized calcium may suppress the fetal parathyroid glands, leading to hypocalcemia after birth. If untreated, hypocalcemia can result in neurological symptoms, including seizures, headaches, and neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium: Serum potassium is not directly related to hypoglycemia in infants of diabetic mothers. The primary concern in this scenario is hypocalcemia rather than potassium imbalance.

 

Option B. CBC: While a complete blood count (CBC) can provide useful information, it is not specifically related to the metabolic risks associated with infants of diabetic mothers. Serum calcium is a more appropriate investigation in this context.

 

Option C. Serum chloride: Serum chloride levels do not have a direct connection with hypoglycemia or the other metabolic issues typically seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Therefore, it is not the most relevant test in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In infants of diabetic mothers, it is crucial to monitor serum calcium levels alongside blood glucose to detect and manage hypocalcemia, which can have significant neurological implications if untreated.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myxedema coma

 

Myxedema coma is part of myxedema crisis which can be considered as “Decompensated Hypothyroidism”, where, organ dysfunctions occur compared to hypothyroidism (functioning is fairly preserved).

 

It is characterized by:

 

  1. Hypothermia
  2. Hypotension
  3. Hypoventilation
  4. Altered Mental Status (including coma /Hypersomnolence)
  5. Hyponatremia (Euvolemic similar to SIADH)
  6. Hypoglycemia

 

Adrenal insufficiency may co-exist. Hence, treated with IV steroids + IV levothyroxine/Nasogastric LT4.

 

Steroid given to prevent precipitation of adrenal crisis as well.

 

Often precipitated by infection or major cardiopulmonary or neurologic illness. Rarely precipitated by severe cold climate exposure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No obvious source, fever suggestive of septic shock given in the question.

 

Option B. No cardiac symptoms, elevated JVP, cardiac risk factors.

 

Option C. Dry-skin, hypotension, hypothermia, menorrhagia as presentation of Hypoglycemia is unlikely.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases where a patient presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status, especially in conjunction with a history suggestive of hypothyroidism, myxedema coma should be considered a critical diagnosis. Immediate and aggressive thyroid hormone replacement therapy is essential for survival.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

 

Mechanisms of glaucoma. The two main theories regarding the mechanism of glaucoma in eyes with SWS are developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle and elevated episcleral venous pressure, each of which leads to aqueous outflow restriction leading to rise in IOP. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: This is inflammation of the uvea and not a typical manifestation of SWS.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a group of genetic disorders that affect the retina's ability to respond to light, not commonly associated with SWS.

 

Option C. Keratitis: Inflammation or infection of the cornea, not linked to SWS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those presenting with facial port-wine stains and neurological symptoms, glaucoma is a critical ocular manifestation to consider. Regular ophthalmic evaluations are essential due to the high incidence of glaucoma in these patients, focusing on managing elevated IOP to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

 

Leptin is a peptide hormone released from adipocytes

 

Leptin plays an important role in controlling the adipose tissue and food intake.

 

Actions of leptin:

 

  • Acts on hypothalamus and inhibits the feeding center, resulting in stoppage of food intake
  • Stimulates the metabolic reactions involved in utilization of fat stored in adipose tissue for energy. Thus, the circulating leptin level informs the brain about the energy storage and the necessity to regulate metabolic reactions, food intake and body weight
  • Elevated leptin levels might have a permissive effect on the pubertal process and pubertal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH: Incorrect as GnRH directly stimulates the secretion of LH and FSH, which are critical for puberty but not considered permissive.

 

Option C. Insulin: While it plays a supportive role in general growth and development, it is not specifically permissive for the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. GH: Growth hormone is vital for growth and development during puberty but does not have a direct permissive role in the initiation of puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin serves a permissive role in puberty, indicating to the hypothalamus that sufficient energy reserves are available for the safe progression of reproductive development. This hormone essentially "permits" the initiation of puberty when energy conditions are met.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation
Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.32, pCO2 = 50, HCO3- = 29. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate:

 

pH = 7.12 (<7.4 = acidemic/acidosis) → Metabolic vs respiratory (pCO2 > 40= Respiratory drive is towards acidosis while metabolic [HCO3-] is towards alkalosis) → Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation (Every 10 ↑ pCO2 = ↑4 HCO3- = Chronic).

 

These findings are characteristic of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. In respiratory acidosis, the body compensates by increasing renal reabsorption of bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions resulting from elevated CO2 levels, which shifts the pH back towards normal. This compensation is a slower process and suggests a chronic respiratory condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where ABG shows a low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory high bicarbonate, the diagnosis is typically respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. This is indicative of a chronic condition where the body adjusts bicarbonate levels to buffer the increased acidity due to CO2 retention.

 

Reference - Harrison/Acid-Base Disturbances

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation:

 

Presynaptic secretory vesicles are indicated by the asterisk in the electron micrograph. The structure with the arrowhead represents postsynaptic density.

 

Neurons produce secretory vesicles, which are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.

 

Synapse - electron microscopy

 

 

On electron microscopy:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria- On an electron microscope, mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies 0.5-2.0 micron long, with an outer and inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B.  Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory vesicles are essential for neurotransmission at synapses, and play the critical role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she states that she is a major and is married to the man. X-ray images of her elbow, wrist, and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 21 to 22 years

 

The most approximate age of this girl is 21-22 years. This conclusion is based on the X-ray findings of her bone centers:

 

  • The elbow joint centers (lower end of the humerus, upper end of the radius, and olecranon) are fused, indicating that the age is more than 16 years.
  • The wrist joint centers (lower end of the ulna and radius) are also fused, indicating the age is more than 19 years.
  • The hip bone centers (head of the femur, greater and lesser trochanter, ischial tuberosity) are fused, which typically occurs at or after 21 years.

 

Thus, based on the fusion of the ischial tuberosity and other bone centers, the girl’s age is estimated to be approximately 21 to 22 years, making her legally an adult.

 

Educational Objective:


Bone fusion patterns are critical in age estimation. Complete fusion of the wrist, elbow, and pelvic joints typically indicates an age of over 21 years, which is crucial in legal cases determining whether an individual is a minor or an adult.

questions.text: What is the definitive approach for managing uncontrollable vertigo caused by Meniere's disease?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labyrinthectomy

 

Definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease is labyrinthectomy.

 

The step-up management of Meniere’s disease is

 

  1. Dietary changes – low salt and caffeine free diet
  2. First-line medical treatment to prevent recurrence of vertigo may include betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg thrice daily and/or diuretics. Betahistine has a limited side effect profile while diuretics can cause electrolyte disturbances, potentially interacting with patient-specific drugs and conditions.
  3. Salvage treatment in case of medical treatment failure may include repetitive intratympanic injections of dexamethasone.
  4. In refractory cases after intratympanic injection of dexamethasone, intratympanic injection of gentamicin (as-needed) can be offered (recommendation grade A). This treatment is based on the vestibulotoxic effect of gentamicin and aims to destroy vestibular hair cell function (therefore also called partial chemo labyrinthectomy).
  5. Surgical destruction (Labyrinthectomy, Vestibular nerve section): Labyrinthectomy totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function and are thus used only when cochlear function is not serviceable and when conservative treatments fail. It has shown the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), and is considered as the single definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide: This medication is not typically used as a definitive treatment for Meniere's disease. It may be used in some cases for its diuretic effect to manage symptoms, but it does not address the root causes or provide long-term control of vertigo.

 

Option C. Vestibular neurectomy: This surgical procedure involves severing the vestibular nerve to alleviate vertigo while preserving hearing. It is considered for patients where hearing preservation is a priority, but it is not as definitive as labyrinthectomy for completely eliminating vertigo.

 

Option D. Intratympanic gentamicin: This treatment involves injecting gentamicin, a vestibulotoxic antibiotic, into the middle ear to chemically ablate vestibular function. It is used as a salvage treatment for vertigo control in Meniere's disease when other medical treatments fail. However, it is not considered as definitive as labyrinthectomy due to its potential for hearing loss and the need for repeated treatments in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Meniere's disease who have debilitating vertigo and no serviceable hearing in the affected ear, labyrinthectomy offers a definitive solution with a very high success rate in eliminating vertigo. This surgical option is reserved for severe cases where other less invasive treatments have been exhausted.

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

The image shows a bifocal spectacle that is made of lenses with two different optical powers (upper half for distant vision and lower half for near vision). Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, primarily affects near vision, necessitating correction that provides a uniform optical adjustment across the entire lens surface to assist with close vision tasks, rather than segmented correction like in bifocals.

 

Other Options:

 

Bifocal spectacles are typically used for treating following conditions:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifocal spectacles are not typically used for treating hypermetropia, which generally requires a uniform optical correction across the entire lens to aid in near tasks. Bifocals are instead beneficial in conditions requiring simultaneous correction for near and far vision, such as presbyopia, or specific needs following surgical interventions like in aphakia and pediatric pseudophakia.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaints of umbilical discharge. Abdominal examination was otherwise normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG Abdomen

 

The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly with an apparent discharging sinus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a safe and non-invasive imaging technique commonly used to evaluate abdominal conditions in pediatric patients. It is particularly useful for assessing the umbilical region and identifying any abnormalities that may be causing the umbilical discharge. USG provides real-time imaging and can help in diagnosing conditions such as umbilical granulomas, urachal abnormalities, or other underlying issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI Abdomen: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) of the abdomen is a valuable diagnostic tool for various abdominal conditions. However, in the case of a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge, an ultrasound (USG) is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. MRI is generally reserved for more complex or specific cases.

 

Option C. СЕСТ: CECT may be done after USG if further information was desired.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: Performing an exploratory laparotomy as the initial step in a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge and an otherwise normal abdominal examination would be overly aggressive and not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

 

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities according to the part of the duct that is persistent.
  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel's diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical sinus, likely to be the case here.
  • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.
