A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome, is characterized by a combination of asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems.

 

The clinical triad of skin lesions (such as purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex (manifesting as numbness, pain, or muscle weakness typically in the limbs), and eosinophilia is highly suggestive of this condition. EGPA is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis but differs from others in its prominent eosinophilic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Typically associated with hepatitis C infection and features immune complexes in the blood that precipitate in the cold. It commonly presents with palpable purpura, joint pains, and kidney involvement but not typically with eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that may present with similar features including neuropathy and skin lesions but does not typically include eosinophilia as a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA): Primarily affects large vessels, particularly the temporal arteries, and presents with symptoms such as headache, jaw claudication, and potential blindness. It does not feature the triad of skin lesions, mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EGPA is a distinctive form of vasculitis marked by asthma, eosinophilia, and a systemic vasculitis involving skin and nerves among other systems. Its recognition is crucial due to the need for early and aggressive treatment to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

choices.text: Vicarious liability
Doctrine of negligent choice
Contributory negligence
Borrowed servant doctrine

questions.text: A surgeon lends his assistant to a physician; the new employer is responsible for his actions by? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Borrowed servant doctrine  

 

The borrowed servant rule is a legal doctrine in which an employer is held liable for the actions of a temporary employee. When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily surrenders control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Vicarious liability: Incorrect. Vicarious liability is a legal principle where an employer is held responsible for the actions of their employees while they are performing their job duties. However, it does not specifically address situations involving borrowed employees.

 

Option B. Doctrine of negligent choice: Incorrect. The doctrine of negligent choice involves holding someone liable for choosing an incompetent or unfit person to perform a task. This doctrine is not directly relevant to the situation described.

 

Option C. Contributory negligence: Incorrect. Contributory negligence refers to a situation where the injured party has, through their own negligence, contributed to the harm they suffered. It does not apply to the responsibility of an employer for the actions of a borrowed employee.

 

Educational objective

 

The borrowed servant doctrine holds that the borrowing employer assumes liability for the actions of an employee borrowed from another employer during the period of borrowing. This ensures that the temporary employer is responsible for supervising and controlling the borrowed employee.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose


During neonatal resuscitation, suctioning is performed to clear the airway of the newborn to ensure effective breathing. The correct order for suctioning is mouth first, followed by the nose. This order is crucial because suctioning the nose first could cause the newborn to gasp and potentially aspirate any fluids or secretions present in the mouth.

 

Technical Details:

 

  • The suction catheter typically used is 12 or 14 French, and the suction pressure is maintained between 80-100 mmHg.
  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 39 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The appropriate timing of delivery in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) whose blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin is at or after 39 weeks of gestation. This recommendation is based on the following considerations:

 

  • Lung Maturity: GDM pregnancies are associated with a delay in fetal lung maturity. Routine delivery before 39 weeks is generally not recommended to avoid respiratory complications in the newborn.
  • Induction of Labor: If the patient with well-controlled GDM has not delivered spontaneously by 39 weeks, induction of labor should be scheduled at or after 39 weeks to minimize the risks associated with GDM and to ensure fetal maturity.

 

Other important points in GDM:

 

  • Avoid Past Dates: Delivery should not be delayed beyond the expected due date to prevent complications.
  • Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia: There is an increased risk of shoulder dystocia in infants of mothers with GDM.
  • Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS): Considered if the estimated fetal weight is greater than 4.5 kg to avoid complications during vaginal delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with well-controlled gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) on insulin, the appropriate gestational age for delivery is at or after 39 weeks to ensure fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/National_Guidelines_for_Diagnosis_&_Management_of_Gestational_Diabetes_Mellitus.pdf

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3. Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8

questions.text: According to the current biomedical waste management guidelines, which colored bin should be used for the disposal of blood bag? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow bin 

 

  • Yellow Bin: Used for human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste, expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, and clinical lab waste.
  • This includes items such as body parts, blood bags, and items contaminated with body fluids.
  • The disposal methods typically involve incineration, plasma pyrolysis, deep burial, or chemical treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

 

The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days.

 

The causative agent is Chlamydia trachomatis, serovars L1, L2, L3. Chlamydia is a ubiquitous ovoid or obligate intracellular bacteria.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum primarily affects the lymphatic system. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars extend from the primary infection site to the regional lymph nodes and cause a lymphoproliferative reaction, facilitated by binding of Chlamydia trachomatis to the epithelial cells. Binding occurs via heparin sulfate receptors.

 

The basis for a definitive diagnosis of LGV is on serology tests (complement fixation or micro-immunofluorescence) or identification of Chlamydia trachomatis in genital, rectal and lymph node specimens (by culture, nucleic acid amplification test or direct immunofluorescence).

 

Educational Objective

 

The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner plexiform layer

 

The inner plexiform layer is marked in the above histological image of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner plexiform layer of the retina is a crucial site for synaptic activity among various retinal cells, playing a key role in the preprocessing of visual information before it is sent to the brain. Recognizing this layer and understanding its function are important for comprehending the overall neural circuitry of the retina.

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate termination

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described indicates fetal compromise, specifically with the findings of oligohydramnios (AFI = 5) and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler. These are signs of severe placental insufficiency and fetal distress.

 

  • Absent or Reversed End-Diastolic Flow: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound indicating severe fetal compromise. The absence of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery suggests that the fetus is not receiving adequate blood flow, leading to an increased risk of hypoxia and stillbirth.
  • Management:
    • Immediate Termination: For pregnancies beyond 34 weeks, immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further fetal compromise. This is because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits, given the significant risk of fetal hypoxia and potential demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: This is not appropriate because the immediate risk to the fetus requires prompt delivery.

 

Option C. Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion: Continuous monitoring is insufficient in this scenario as the condition indicates severe fetal distress requiring urgent intervention.

 

Option D. Terminate after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is not appropriate due to the immediate risk of fetal compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe fetal compromise indicated by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler, especially beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate termination of the pregnancy is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential stillbirth.

 

Ref: Page no 2141, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Burst forming units
Colony forming units
Late erythroblast stage

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burst forming units

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) primarily acts on early erythroid progenitor cells, particularly the Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid (BFU-E). The BFU-E is among the earliest erythroid progenitor cells and requires EPO to proliferate and differentiate into more mature forms of red blood cell precursors.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • BFU-E: The Burst Forming Unit-Erythroid is sensitive to erythropoietin and under its influence can proliferate and differentiate, giving rise to Colony Forming Unit-Erythroid (CFU-E).
  • CFU-E: This stage follows BFU-E and leads to the development of more differentiated erythroid cells.
  • Role of EPO: EPO binds to specific receptors on the surface of erythroid progenitor cells, initiating a cascade of intracellular events that promote cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Colony forming units: This is a later stage than BFU-E and is also influenced by EPO but not the earliest.

 

Option C. Late erythroblast stage: EPO's influence diminishes as cells mature to this stage.

 

Option D. Normoblast stage: This is a more mature stage of erythroid development where EPO has minimal effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is most effective at the burst forming unit stage of red blood cell development, where it stimulates the proliferation and differentiation of these early progenitor cells into more mature red blood cells.

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 6 to 7 months

 

Crown rump length + length of lower limb = crown heel length

 

According to the Rule of Haase

 

  • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/ first 5 months).
  • Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/ last 5 months).

 

Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 31 cm.

 

Hence, gestational age = 31 / 5 = 6-7 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rule of Haase can be used to estimate gestational age from fetal measurements. For a crown-heel length greater than 25 cm, the gestational age is calculated by dividing the crown-heel length by 5.

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

 

Contraceptive methods can be classified into temporary (reversible) and permanent (irreversible) methods.

 

  • Permanent Methods (Irreversible):
    • Laparoscopic Tubal Ligation: This is a surgical procedure where the fallopian tubes are cut, tied, or sealed to prevent pregnancy permanently. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception as it is intended to be a permanent solution for women who do not wish to have more children.
  • Temporary Methods (Reversible):
    • Copper-T (Intrauterine Device - IUD): A long-term but reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.
    • Implanon (Subdermal Contraceptive Implant): A long-term reversible method that can be removed to restore fertility.
    • LNG-IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device): Another long-term reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent (irreversible) method of contraception.

 

Ref: Page no 611, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Weight of a patient before and after a treatment

questions.text: You are working on a research project and need to determine the appropriate usage of the Chi-square test. Which of the following sets of data would be most appropriate for utilizing the Chi-square test? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sex and type of cancer

 

  • The chi-square test is a nonparametric statistical method used to evaluate the significance of an association between two categorical variables.
  • Within the provided choices, the only pair of categorical variables (qualitative data) is sex and type of cancer. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

 

Resistance to ganciclovir (GCV) most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene.

 

Viral UL97 kinase and UL54 DNA polymerase gene mutations are well-documented mechanisms of resistance to current antivirals. The UL97 kinase normally phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of various cellular and viral proteins, and is required for efficient CMV replication. This kinase also effects the initial phosphorylation of GCV that is required for antiviral activity, and UL97 mutations that impair this phosphorylation are the preferred mechanism of GCV resistance.

 

UL54 mutations can confer resistance to all current drugs and may emerge after prolonged GCV therapy to increase the level of resistance conferred by a pre-existing UL97 mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

 

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical. In immunocompromised individuals, CMV can cause various manifestations, including retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis, but watery diarrhea is not the most common manifestation.

 

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscamet. These mutations affect the viral DNA polymerase, leading to cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image shows a right-sided hyperdense area indicative of an acute extradural hemorrhage (EDH). Extradural hemorrhages typically result from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident, and are often arterial in origin, frequently involving the middle meningeal artery (MMA). The classic biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, as observed, does not cross sutures but may cross the midline, distinguishing it from other types of hemorrhages.

 

Right sided hyperdense acute EDH is shown in the NCCT

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage: Typically presents with a crescentic or "banana-shaped" appearance, crosses sutures, and involves bridging veins, usually from lower energy trauma or trivial injuries, which is not compatible with the findings on this CT.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, generally producing a diffuse or layered appearance in the CT, which is not evident here.

 

Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Results in blood within the ventricular system, showing up as hyperdense within the ventricles, not applicable to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S3

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the developing fetus. One of the normal physiological changes includes the presence of the S3 heart sound.

 

  • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.

 

Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. S4 Heart Sound: The S4 sound, or atrial gallop, is generally associated with pathological conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy or myocardial ischemia. It is rare in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is usually indicative of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and is not normal in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Pericardial Knock: This is a sound heard in cases of constrictive pericarditis and is not a normal finding in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S3 heart sound is considered normal during pregnancy due to the increased blood volume and rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles.

 

Ref: Page no 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

The most probable diagnosis is neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

 

NMO is a demyelinating autoimmune disease that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Patients with NMO can present with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis, which can result in decreased visual acuity, as well as myelitis, which can cause weakness, sensory loss, and bladder dysfunction.

 

The patient's history of recurrent episodes of diminution of vision that recovers on treatment with steroids is consistent with optic neuritis, which is a common presenting feature of NMO. The history of transverse myelitis also supports a diagnosis of NMO, as myelitis is a common feature of the disease.

 

Management of acute attacks:

 

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Plasma exchange.

 

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses:

 

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Rituximab
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Azathioprine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: This is a genetic disorder affecting motor functions and does not involve optic neuritis or transverse myelitis.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency affecting the spinal cord, but not specifically linked with optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis (MS): While MS can present with symptoms similar to NMO, including optic neuritis and spinal cord involvement, the pattern of attacks and the severity of symptoms in the context of transverse myelitis point more specifically to NMO, especially considering the distinct pathophysiology and antibody profiles (e.g., anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuromyelitis optica should be considered in patients presenting with recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, especially when there is a good response to steroid treatment. Distinguishing NMO from multiple sclerosis is crucial, as treatment and prognosis differ significantly between these conditions.

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle is absent in which compartment of the leg? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior superficial compartment

 

There is no neurovascular bundle in the leg's posterior superficial compartment.

 

The transverse intermuscular septum divides the posterior compartment of the leg into deep and superficial compartments.

 

The gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soles muscles are found in the posterior superficial compartment.

    

 

Neurovascular components in various compartments of leg are as follows:

 

  • Anterior compartment: Anterior tibial artery and Deep fibular/peroneal nerve
  • Posterior deep compartment: Tibial nerve and posterior tibial vessels in the deep plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment primarily contains the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (fibularis longus and fibularis brevis in newer nomenclature).
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve. The blood supply comes from branches of the anterior tibial and fibular (peroneal) arteries.

 

Option C. Posterior Deep Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment contains the popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. The blood supply primarily comes from the posterior tibial artery.

 

Option D. Anterior Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment houses the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and fibularis (peroneus) tertius.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. The anterior tibial artery supplies blood to this compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Superficial Compartment has the gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris muscles. These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. However, this compartment does not have a specific named artery or vein running through it, as the main vessels (the posterior tibial and fibular arteries and their accompanying veins) are located deep in the leg, closer to the bones. Instead, the vascular supply to these muscles comes from branching vessels that penetrate the compartment.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

 

The inferior olivary nucleus is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry and is responsible for providing input to the Purkinje cells via the climbing fibers. These fibers make direct synaptic connections with Purkinje cells and are involved in the modulation of motor learning, control, and coordination. The inferior olivary nucleus receives a wide range of inputs from other areas of the brain, including the spinal cord and sensory systems, and is thought to play an important role in the integration of sensory and motor information during movement.

 

Excitatory and inhibitory fibres –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raphe nucleus: Primarily associated with serotonin production, influencing many brain functions including mood and sleep, but does not directly connect to Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Vestibular nucleus: Sends information to the cerebellum about head position and movement via mossy fibers, not directly to Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Locus coeruleus: Provides widespread noradrenergic projections that influence arousal and attentiveness, not directly targeting Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

choices.text: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.
It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

 

Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving.

 

Principles of blood administration:

 

  • All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter.
  • A careful aseptic technique should be practiced at all times.
  • Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased.
  • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient's cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature.
  • No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product.
  • Ringer's lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation.
  • After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient's chart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank: This option is incorrect as the emphasis is on completing the transfusion within 4 hours, not just starting it.

 

Option C. No such time restraint and can be done anytime: This is incorrect, as there is a specific time frame to prevent bacterial proliferation.

 

Option D. It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank: This option is incorrect; the recommended maximum time for completion is 4 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank to minimize the risk of bacterial proliferation and ensure patient safety.

choices.text: Type II error is small and we can accept the findings of the study
The probability of false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%
The power of the study to detect the difference between operation A and B is 96%
The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

questions.text: During a journal club discussion on a randomized controlled trial comparing two surgical techniques for direct inguinal hernia, the reported p-value is 0.04. What is the most accurate interpretation of this p-value? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

 

  • With a calculated p-value of 0.04, we can deduce that there is a 4% chance of arriving at a false positive conclusion, suggesting that operation A is superior to operation B.
  • In this context, the p-value of 0.04 attains statistical significance by conventional standards.
  • Consequently, we have grounds to reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis, indicating that operation A outperforms operation B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 suggests that there is a statistically significant difference, at the 5% significance level, between the surgical techniques being compared, assuming the risk of a false positive conclusion is acceptable at 4%.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

 

Germ tube test is a screening test for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. Candida dubliniensis can also form germ tubes and Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that closely resemble germ tubes.

 

Germ tube formation was first reported by Reynolds and Braude and hence the germ tube test is also known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

 

Buds and pseudo-hyphae can be distinguished from germ tubes by the constricted attachment at the point of origin. Germ tubes don’t show constriction at the point of origin.

 

Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis produce short, slender, tube-like structures called germ tubes.

 

The formation of germ tubes is associated with increased synthesis of protein and ribonucleic acid. Various media like fetal bovine serum may be used as a substitute for human pooled serum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: Candida glabrata does not produce germ tubes. It forms small, round yeast cells.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis does not produce germ tubes. It forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that resemble germ tubes, but they show constriction at the point of origin. This is a distinguishing feature from the true germ tubes of Candida albicans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is used for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. It detects the formation of germ tubes, which are characteristic of Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis but not other Candida species. Germ tubes are short, slender, tube-like structures without constriction at their point of origin, differentiating them from pseudohyphae.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

 

Explanation:

 

The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint.  .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.

 

Option C. Distal end of radius: The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:

 

  • Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum

 

Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

questions.text: What is the bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100%

 

Bioavailability of an administered drug is the fraction of that drug that reaches unchanged into systemic circulation. It depends upon 2 factors:

 

  • Absorption of the drug from the site of application
  • First pass metabolism

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously (I.V) is 100% because it is neither subjected to the first-pass metabolism as in oral route nor does it depend on local factors that affect absorption as in subcutaneous, intramuscular, or transdermal. In IV route, the drug is directly delivered to the systemic circulation and hence has the maximum availability for action at the intended site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is 100% because the drug is directly delivered into the systemic circulation without any loss due to absorption barriers or first-pass metabolism.

choices.text: Reassure and to check whether passed in stools

questions.text: A child presents with history of acute dysphagia. CXR is shown below. What is the next best step? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Remove endoscopically

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows a foreign body in the esophagus which is likely to be a button battery as seen by the double margins.

 

 

In profile/ en face: Foreign body is in the esophagus

 

The next step should be to endoscopically removing those batteries as they lead to tissue necrosis by liquefactive necrosis.

 

Patient’s oral intake should be prohibited until the location of the foreign body is confirmed. Never induce vomiting in these patients as it can again lodge back in the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy: Bronchoscopy is not suitable as the foreign body is located in the esophagus, not the airways.

 

Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: This approach is inappropriate due to the urgent risk of tissue damage from the battery; immediate removal is necessary.

 

Option D. Induce vomiting: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated as it can cause further esophageal injury or lead to re-lodgement of the battery in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected ingestion of button batteries as seen on CXR, urgent endoscopic removal is critical to prevent tissue damage and potential complications. Vomiting should never be induced in these situations as it can exacerbate the problem.

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza virus

 

The given image shows the replication of influenza virus.

 

Stages of replication:

 

Replication of influenza A viruses in the lung epithelium.

 

Binding of haemagglutinin (HA), expressed on the surface of the influenza virion, with sialic acid residues linked to cell surface glycans induces binding and fusion of the virion with the plasma membrane of the target cell.

 

The virus then enters the cell via endocytosis or micropinocytosis and is trafficked to the lysosome where acidification activates the proton selective matrix protein-2 viral channel (M2), inducing membrane fusion and dissociation of the viral ribonucleoprotein (RNP) core, which is then transported to the nucleus where viral RNA replication occurs.

 

Progeny viral RNP cores are generated in the cytosol and, with the viral surface proteins, HA and neuraminidase (NA), and other viral proteins, are concentrated in and near lipid rafts at the plasma membrane.

 

Budding of these plasma membrane regions forms complete viral progeny, which is linked to the plasma membrane by HA/sialic acid interactions.

 

Cleavage of sialic acid residues by neuraminidase releases the viral progeny so they are then free to infect other cells, which can be prevented by NA inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis virus: Hepatitis viruses have different replication mechanisms and do not exhibit the specific stages shown in the image for influenza virus.

 

Option C. HIV: HIV is a retrovirus that integrates its RNA into the host DNA using reverse transcriptase, followed by integration into the host genome, which is not depicted in the given image.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have a different replication mechanism involving DNA replication within the nucleus and the formation of nucleocapsids in the nucleus, not shown in the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The replication cycle depicted in the image is characteristic of the influenza virus, involving binding of hemagglutinin (HA) to sialic acid residues, endocytosis, acidification within lysosomes, RNA replication in the nucleus, assembly at the plasma membrane, and release mediated by neuraminidase.

questions.text: In the case of a patient presenting with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, which drug is considered the preferred choice for treatment?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of nodular acne. It comes under grade IV/severe acne.

 

Oral isotretinoin, an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata & recalcitrant acne.

 

Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, with less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

  • Most common form of acne.
  • Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.
  • Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.
  • Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Stages of acne

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment:

 

 

 

BPO= Benzoyl peroxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids particularly corticosteroids, can reduce inflammation and are sometimes used to treat severe inflammatory conditions. However, systemic corticosteroids are generally not a first-line treatment for nodulocystic acne because of their potential side effects, including exacerbating acne upon withdrawal. Intralesional corticosteroids can be used for large, painful nodules but are not the primary treatment for widespread nodulocystic acne.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: It is an antibiotic that can be used to treat acne due to its antibacterial effects against Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes), the bacteria partly responsible for acne. However, it is not as effective as isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and is generally used for less severe forms or when other treatments are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: It is another class of antibiotics used in the treatment of acne. While tetracyclines can be effective for inflammatory acne, they are typically less effective than isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and are not the preferred treatment in such cases.

 

Educational Objective::

 

Isotretinoin is the preferred treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its comprehensive action on reducing sebum production, decreasing inflammation, and normalizing keratinization.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.7 & 90.37

choices.text: Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines
Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the vertical plane
3D imaging is possible in the given condition

questions.text: A mentally challenged person bites his brother on the hand during a physical fight. All of the following statements are true about the given condition except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the vertical plane

 

The correct method for photographing bite marks is to use two scales placed at right angles to each other in the horizontal plane. This positioning ensures that the dimensions and orientation of the bite mark are accurately recorded for forensic analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water: Correct. Swabbing the bite mark is essential for collecting DNA evidence, which can be critical in identifying the biter.

 

Option B. It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: Correct. Bite marks are typically made by the front teeth, especially the incisors and canines, which are used to grasp and tear.

 

Option D. 3D imaging is possible in the given condition: Correct. 3D imaging can be used to analyze bite marks more accurately, providing detailed information about the depth and pattern of the bite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a human bite mark:

 

  • Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
  • It is most commonly caused by front teeth - incisors and canines
  • Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the HORIZONTAL plane
  • 3D imaging is a valuable tool for analysis

questions.text: The normal Doppler waveform of the venous blood flow is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Monophasic

 

Explanation:

 

The normal Doppler waveform for venous blood flow is monophasic. This refers to the uniform, steady, and continuous flow pattern typically observed in veins, unlike the varying phases seen in arterial blood flow. Monophasic waveforms indicate a lack of cardiac modulation and resistance, which is characteristic of venous structures that carry blood under lower pressure and with less force than arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biphasic: Generally observed in visceral arteries, biphasic waveforms show two distinct directional phases in the blood flow, reflecting the resistance encountered by the blood as it moves through these arteries.

 

 

Option C. Triphasic: This waveform is characteristic of extremity arteries and includes three phases—forward flow, brief reverse flow, and forward flow again, which correspond to the cardiac cycle's effects on arterial blood movement.

 

 

Option D. Absent flow: This is not a normal finding and indicates a blockage or absence of blood flow, which requires further investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doppler waveforms refer to the morphology of pulsatile blood flow velocity tracings on spectral Doppler ultrasound. 

 

In Doppler ultrasound, the normal venous waveform is monophasic, indicating a steady flow without the complex fluctuations seen in arterial blood flow.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS

 

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications. 
  • Most common elbow fractures – 50-70%
  • Mechanism:
    • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
    • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles. 
  • Pathoanatomy:
    • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles. 
  • Types:
    • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment. 
    • The extension type is the commoner (98%) of the two. 
    • In this, the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
    • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and cast
    • If conservative management fails or if fracture is displaced, closed reduction and K-wire fixation is done.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion – most common 
    • Posteromedial displacement develops cubitus varus/gunstock deformity
    • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves – transient neuropraxia occurs 
    • Vessel injury: Brachial artery 
    • Volkmann’s ischemia and compartment syndrome 
    • Elbow stiffness 
    • Myositis ossificans 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. It is commonly associated with dinner fork deformity. It is treated successfully with a hand-shaking cast. Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Malunion is the 2nd most common complication, leading to dinner fork deformity. Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of sudeck’s dystrophy in the upper limb. 

 

 

Option B. Lateral epicondyle fracture. Lateral humeral condyle fractures are the second most commonly encountered elbow fractures after supracondylar fractures in the pediatric age group. These fractures are intra-articular and are prone to displacement owing to the attachment of the forearm extensor muscles on the lateral condyle. Due to this, they can produce various complications, including elbow deformity, if not appropriately managed. Displaced fractures are at a higher risk of non-union. Malunion, cubitus varus, avascular necrosis, and post-operative infection are recognized complications following surgery. The most common mechanism is a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination. Fractures with <2mm displacement can have conservative treatment. The indications of surgery are fracture displacement >2 mm and articular surface incongruency. Closed reduction and percutaneous fixation are options.

 

 

Option C. Medial epicondyle fracture. A medial epicondyle fracture is an avulsion injury of the attachment of the common flexors of the forearm. The injury is usually extra-articular but can be sometimes associated with an elbow dislocation. Medial epicondyle fractures are common and account for 10% of all elbow fractures in children. They occur between the ages of 7-15 years. They are usually a result from an avulsion injury caused by a valgus stress at the elbow and contraction of the flexor muscles. Potential complications include medial elbow instability and nonunion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a gunstock deformity i.e., cubitus varus deformity of the elbow after malunion of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

questions.text:
Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GFM for a patient with the data given below? (AIIMS May 2018)

 

Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6

Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45

Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20

Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure =10

Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure =0
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 15 mmHg

 

Four primary forces that determine whether fluid will move out of the blood into the interstitial fluid or in the opposite direction. These forces are:

 

  1. The capillary pressure (Pc), which tends to force fluid outward through the capillary membrane.
  2. The interstitial fluid pressure (Pif), which tends to force fluid inward through the capillary membrane when Pif is positive but outward when Pif is negative.
  3. The capillary plasma colloid osmotic pressure (Pp), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid inward through the capillary membrane.
  4. The interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure (Cif), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid outward through the capillary membrane.

 

If the sum of these forces, the net filtration pressure, is positive, there will be a net fluid filtration across the capillaries. If the sum of the Starling forces is negative, there will be a net fluid absorption from the interstitial spaces into the capillaries.

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) is calculated as:

 

NFP = Pc - Pif - Pp + Cif


Where Pc – Capillary pressure, Pif is Interstitial fluid pressure, Pp is plasma colloid osmotic pressure, Cif is interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

 

Therefore, Net filtration pressure = 45 – 10 – 20 + 0 = 15mmHg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) in the glomerulus, essential for kidney filtration, is calculated based on the differences between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures inside and outside the glomerular capillaries. In this scenario, an NFP of 15 mmHg favors the formation of urine by pushing fluid out of blood vessels into the Bowman's capsule.

choices.text: Artemether plus lumefantrine
Artesunate plus Sulfadoxine plus pyrimethamine

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from west Garo Hill district of Meghalaya presents to the Civil Hospital with intermittent fever, chills, and malaise. Laboratory findings confirm the diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria. The region is known for its Multidrug- resistant strains of P. falciparum. Which of the following antimalarial regimens is considered the most appropriate first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas with multidrug-resistant strains? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artemether plus lumefantrine

 

The Drug of choice treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

 Artemisinin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For P. falciparum malaria in regions with known drug resistance, artemether plus lumefantrine is the most effective first-line treatment, ensuring rapid and sustained clearance of the malaria parasite.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Schedule H drugs

 

Under the "Drugs and Cosmetics Act," certain schedules classify drugs based on various criteria, including the need for prescription, potential for abuse, and manufacturing practices.

 

  • Schedule H drugs: These drugs can only be sold with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. They are labeled with "Rx" written in black color to indicate that they should be dispensed only on prescription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schedule M drugs: These pertain to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) for pharmaceuticals and do not indicate a requirement for prescription-based sale.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs: This schedule lists diseases and ailments for which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure. It does not pertain to prescription requirements.

 

Option D. Schedule X drugs: These are psychotropic substances with a high potential for abuse and must be sold with a valid prescription. While Schedule X drugs also require a prescription, the question specifically asks about drugs that should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner, making Schedule H drugs the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The important schedules under the “Drugs and Cosmetics Act” are:

 

  • Schedule H – The drugs that can be sold only by prescription where Rx is written in black color.
  • Schedule H1 – for antibiotics where Rx is written in red color.
  • Schedule G – Drugs that need labelling as “Dangerous to use except under medical supervision.”
  • Schedule X – Psychotropic drugs that have a high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.
  • Schedule P drug – describes the life period of drugs in months (unless otherwise specified) between the date of manufacture and date of expiry.
  • Schedule M – GMP or Good Manufacturing Practices.
  • Schedule J - List of diseases and ailments which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure

questions.text: Fluoroacetate is a component of pesticides. Which of the following metabolic pathways is inhibited by this compound? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

 

Sodium fluoroacetate, is usually used as a rodenticide. It is highly toxic towards humans and other mammals through inhibition of the enzyme aconitase in the tricarboxylic acid cycle (metabolic uncoupler), caused by 'lethal synthesis' of an isomer of fluorocitrate (FC). FA is found in a range of plant species and their ingestion can cause the death of ruminant animals.

 

Inhibition of the TCA Cycle by Fluoroacetate:

  • Aconitase: Converts citrate to aconitate.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate is metabolized to fluorocitrate, which inhibits aconitase, leading to the accumulation of citrate and disruption of the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolytic pathway:

  • Function: Converts glucose to pyruvate, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not affect glycolysis.

 

Option C. Oxidative phosphorylation:

  • Function: Produces ATP through the electron transport chain and ATP synthase.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option D. ETC (Electron Transport Chain):

  • Function: Transfers electrons from NADH and FADH2 to oxygen, generating ATP.
  • Inhibition: Fluoroacetate does not directly inhibit the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of TCA Cycle

questions.text: In the motor homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precision of movements

 

Precision of movements has maximum representation in the motor homunculus.

 

In the sensory homunculus, the relative sizes of the cortical areas is proportional to the use of the part, the number of specialized sensory receptors and precision required by respective peripheral area of the body.

 

Some body parts like lips are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex followed by the face and thumb while the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low control and skilled movements: Incorrect, as areas requiring low control do not have extensive cortical representation.

 

Option B. More muscle fibres are present: Incorrect, as the size of representation in the motor homunculus is not based on the number of muscle fibers, but rather on the precision and complexity of movements.

 

Option D. Intensity of perception: Incorrect, as intensity of perception is related to sensory input and the sensory homunculus, not the motor homunculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The motor homunculus has maximum representation for body parts requiring precision of movements, reflecting the complexity and intricacy needed for fine motor control.

questions.text:
Which of the following organelles is absent in the area of the cardiac muscle marked:  
(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are not typically concentrated in the marked perinuclear area of cardiac muscle cells. Instead, lysosomes are distributed throughout the cytoplasm of the cell. This means that they are present in the cell but do not show a significant concentration or structure in the indicated area of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

In cardiac muscle cells, mitochondria are abundant due to the high-energy demand for contraction, and endoplasmic reticulum (sarcoplasmic reticulum) and Golgi bodies are usually present in the perinuclear area for synthesis and modification of proteins and other important molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are highly abundant in cardiac muscle cells, particularly near areas that need significant energy. The heart has a high demand for ATP due to its continuous contractions, and mitochondria are essential for this energy supply.

 

Option C. Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies are present in cardiac muscle cells, often localized around the perinuclear area. They are important for modifying, packaging, and sorting proteins, which are needed in various cellular functions, including those in muscle contraction and maintenance.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER): The endoplasmic reticulum (or sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells) is crucial for calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction. It is indeed present in cardiac muscle cells and has a significant role in the regulation of contraction and relaxation cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are widely distributed throughout the cytoplasm of cells,

 

  1. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles 
  2. The enzymes within lysosomes are responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials, such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and even organelles.
  3. Lysosomes play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis by recycling and eliminating unwanted or damaged cellular components through a process known as autophagy.
  4. The acidic environment within lysosomes (pH around 4.5-5) is necessary for the optimal activity of the digestive enzymes.

 

Lysosomal storage disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease, occur when there is a malfunction or deficiency of enzymes within lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested materials and subsequent cellular dysfunction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female victim of RTA presents to the ER. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen is soft. The probable diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, tympanic note (hyper-resonant) on percussion, and decreased breath sounds on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure in the chest cavity. This condition can compress the lungs and the great vessels in the chest, causing respiratory distress, hypotension, elevated JVP, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Tympanic percussion note over the right chest is consistent with air in the pleural space. Ecchymosis (bruising) over the chest wall can result from trauma and rib fractures associated with tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with symptoms such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins (Jugular Venous Pressure - JVP). While elevated JVP is mentioned in the scenario, the other symptoms associated with cardiac tamponade, such as muffled heart sounds and hypotension, are not present.

 

Option C. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion involves the accumulation of fluid around the heart. While it can cause elevated JVP, it typically presents with other cardiac symptoms, such as muffled heart sounds and chest pain. The scenario does not mention these cardiac-specific symptoms.

 

Option D. Massive hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to a significant accumulation of blood in the pleural space. It can cause decreased breath sounds, but it is not typically associated with a tympanic percussion note or elevated JVP unless there is concurrent tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately causes collapse of the affected lung.

 

It is characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment must never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation. Management includes:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

questions.text: The structure marked with the black arrow in the given picture arises from the ……… (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.

 

Hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe of the brain.

 

The hippocampus is critical for the formation and retrieval of memories, particularly episodic memories. It's also involved in spatial navigation. Damage or atrophy of the hippocampus can result in difficulties forming new memories. Conditions like Alzheimer's disease often exhibit significant hippocampal atrophy.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Mamillary body: Part of the diencephalon, present at the base of the brain, posterior to the pituitary gland.

 

  • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.

 

Option C. Thalamus: Positioned centrally in the brain, the thalamus is a large mass of gray matter deep within the brain. It is part of the diencephalon.

 

  • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.

 

Option D. Amygdala: Located in the anterior portion of the temporal lobe, deep within the brain.

 

  • The amygdala plays a pivotal role in processing emotions, particularly fear and pleasure. It helps determine which memories are stored and where they are stored based on emotional significance. Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronal Section of Brain

questions.text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/news/item/20-12-2022-WHO-updates-recommendations-on-HPV-vaccination-schedule

questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear

 

Golgi complex is located in supranuclear cytoplasm in serous acinar cells. Serous acinar cells are generally found in pancreas and the submandibular salivary glands.

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi complex is involved in the modification and packaging of secretory proteins into vesicles that can be transported to the apical surface of the cell for release into the ducts or glands. The supranuclear location of the Golgi complex in these cells allows for efficient transport of these vesicles to the apical surface for secretion.

 

In contrast, other organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, and rough endoplasmic reticulum are typically located in the basal or perinuclear regions of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal: Incorrect, as the basal region is typically where the nucleus and other organelles like mitochondria are located.

 

Option C. Adjacent to nucleus: Incorrect, while the Golgi apparatus is near the nucleus, it is specifically located above the nucleus in the supranuclear position in serous acinar cells.

 

Option D. Apical: Incorrect, as the Golgi apparatus itself is not located in the apical region, though it directs secretory vesicles to this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In serous acinar cells, the Golgi apparatus is typically located in the supranuclear region, facilitating the modification and transport of secretory proteins for efficient secretion into the glandular ducts.

choices.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed
Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about superior mesenteric artery syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

 

In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees, which normally is between 38-65 degrees.

 

This statement is incorrect. In SMAS, the angle between the SMA and aorta is typically less than 20 to 25 degrees, not more than 70 degrees. The narrowing of this angle contributes to the compression of the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Third part of duodenum is compressed: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome involves the compression of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA and the aorta.

 

Option C. Surgical management is by Duodenojejunostomy: This statement is correct. One of the surgical treatments for SMAS is Duodenojejunostomy, which involves creating an opening between the duodenum and the jejunum to bypass the compressed area.

 

Option D. Also known as Wilkie's Syndrome: This statement is correct. Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome is also known as Wilkie's Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome, is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures. Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting.

 

 

 

SMA syndrome is associated with:

 

  • Rapid growth during childhood
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the GIT
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta

 

Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice.

 

Treatment involves measures to promote weight gain like NJ feeds, which will lead to widening to aortomesenteric angle (due to deposition of fat). If it fails, then a duodeno-jejunal bypass is done.

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Volume of distribution

 

Loading dose = Volume of Distribution * Target plasma concentration.

 

Loading dose is the high initial dose of the drug that is initially given to cover the distribution so that the desired action can take place. In other words, when the time to reach a steady-state is long, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance is a measure of the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug but does not determine the loading dose. It is more relevant to the maintenance dose.

 

Option C. Plasma half-life: The half-life of a drug determines how long it stays in the body but is not directly used to calculate the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of the administered dose that reaches the systemic circulation. While important for understanding the effective dose, it does not govern the calculation of the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of a drug is primarily governed by its volume of distribution, which helps achieve the desired plasma concentration quickly, especially when the drug has a long half-life.

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the boy. Identify the approximate age of the girl from the Xray picture of her pelvis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 21 years

 

The ischial tuberosity in the X ray is fused, hence the age is > 21 years

 

Some students can get confused and are not able to distinguish whether ischial tuberosity has fused or not yet appeared.
