It is not possible that ischial tuberosity has not yet appeared because the upper end of femur (head, greater trochanter, lesser trochanter) has fused with shaft which occurs between 17- 19 years, whereas ischial tuberosity appears earlier at 16 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Femur

 

Upper end of Femur is composed of three centres:

 

  • Head – 1 yr (A)             
  • Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)
  • Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)          

 

These three centres fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is in the early stages of developing a new antihypertensive medication. They are planning to conduct several phases of clinical trials to assess different aspects of the drug. As part of this process, the research team is set to embark on Phase 1 of the trial. In the context of clinical trial phases, what is the primary objective of this initial phase? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Safety 

 

  • Phase 1 of clinical trials is critically important as it marks the first introduction of a new drug into human subjects.
  • The primary focus during this phase is to evaluate the safety of the drug.

 

Key elements assessed in Phase 1 include:

 

  • Safety & Non-toxicity.
  • Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prostate

 

Prostate Cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

 

Prostate cancer tends to metastasize to bones via periprostatic venous plexus (Bateson) rather than the liver. Bone metastases are a hallmark of advanced prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is one of the most common sites of metastasis for colon cancer, and it frequently spreads to the liver through the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases in breast cancer are not uncommon, and the liver is considered a potential site of spread for breast cancer cells.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma is known for its propensity to metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases are common in advanced melanoma cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.

 

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Azithromycin, doxycycline

 

The DOC for scrub typhus is Doxycycline, but it cannot be used during pregnancy as it can lead to bone growth abnormality in the newborn. So, in that case, to treat Scrub Typhus in Pregnancy, we use Azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloramphenicol, doxycycline: Chloramphenicol is not the first-line treatment for scrub typhus, and doxycycline is indeed used for non-pregnant individuals, but this pair does not cover the correct alternatives during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Doxycycline, doxycycline: This option does not address the contraindication of doxycycline during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline, azithromycin: This reverses the correct pair; azithromycin is used during pregnancy, not doxycycline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus in pregnant women is azithromycin, while doxycycline is used for non-pregnant individuals.

questions.text: Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety

 

Therapeutic Index tells us about the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as follows:

 

Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50

 

• TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose at which there were toxic effects at 50% of the subjects

• ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Efficacy: Efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce, regardless of dose. The therapeutic index does not measure this.

 

Option C. Potency: Potency is the amount of drug needed to produce a given effect. It is not assessed by the therapeutic index.

 

Option D. Toxicity: While toxicity is a component of the therapeutic index (TD50), the index itself is used to measure the safety margin rather than toxicity alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of a drug, indicating the margin between effective and toxic doses. A higher therapeutic index means a drug is safer, with a lower risk of adverse effects at therapeutic doses.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause flagellated pigmentation of skin? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bleomycin

 

Bleomycin is the chemotherapeutic drug that is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation in the skin. Another side effect of Bleomycin is pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxorubicin: This chemotherapeutic agent is known for causing cardiotoxicity and myelosuppression, but it does not typically cause flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Vincristine: This drug is associated with neurotoxicity, particularly peripheral neuropathy, but it does not cause flagellated hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Minocycline: This antibiotic can cause skin pigmentation, but it is not typically flagellated. The pigmentation with minocycline tends to be more diffuse and can affect the skin, nails, and other tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleomycin is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation of the skin as a unique side effect. It can also cause pulmonary fibrosis, making it important to monitor patients for respiratory symptoms during treatment.

choices.text: Unfractionated Heparin
Low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Low molecular weight heparin

 

LMWH is the anticoagulant of choice for the treatment of Cancer associated thromboembolism. It has a long half-life, higher bioavailability and does not require anticoagulant monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated Heparin: While effective, it requires continuous intravenous infusion and frequent monitoring of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), making it less convenient for long-term management.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin requires regular monitoring of the international normalized ratio (INR) to maintain therapeutic levels, which can be challenging in cancer patients due to potential drug interactions and varying dietary intake.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. Although effective, it is not the first choice for cancer-associated thromboembolism due to limited evidence compared to LMWH and potential for drug interactions and gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for managing cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its long half-life, higher bioavailability, and the convenience of not requiring routine anticoagulant monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following new drugs has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Edaravone

 

Edaravone is an FDA approved drug used in the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

 

It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress although the exact mechanism of action is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piracetam: Piracetam is used off-label for cognitive enhancement and the treatment of myoclonus. It is not approved for the treatment of ALS.

 

Option C. Dabrafenib: Dabrafenib is a targeted therapy used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not used for ALS.

 

Option D. Trametinib: Trametinib is also used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not indicated for ALS.

 

Educational Objective

 

Edaravone is the new drug approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), primarily due to its free radical scavenging properties that may help reduce oxidative stress, a factor involved in the disease's progression.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metoclopramide

 

Metoclopramide is an anti-emetic that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can cross the blood brain barrier and can lead to Dopaminergic blockade in the various parts of the brain leading to Acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, Parkinsonism etc.

 

Domperidone is also a D2 Receptor blocker, but cannot cross the BBB, therefore it does not produce such side effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that does not typically cause extrapyramidal side effects. It is used to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions and to treat bradycardia.

 

Option B. Ranitidine: Ranitidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It does not have significant central nervous system effects or cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Domperidone: Domperidone is also a dopamine D2 receptor blocker used as an anti-emetic. However, it does not cross the blood-brain barrier effectively and therefore does not typically cause central nervous system side effects like metoclopramide.

 

Educational Objective

 

Metoclopramide, an anti-emetic that blocks D2 receptors and crosses the blood-brain barrier, can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, and Parkinsonism-like symptoms.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess the extent of drug absorption in a plasma concentration vs. time graph? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Area under the curve

 

In the Concentration-time curve for a given drug, the area under the curve (AUC) tells us about the bioavailability of the drug.

 

The bioavailability of a given drug is defined as the fraction of the given dose that reaches the systemic circulation.

 

It depends on 2 factors:

 

1.Absorption of the drug (More the extent of absorption of the drug, greater is the bioavailability)

 

2.First pass metabolism of the drug (More the first pass metabolism of a drug, lesser is its bioavailability).

 

So, in other words, the AUC tells us about the extent of absorption of the drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax: The time to reach the maximum concentration (Cmax) in plasma. It indicates the rate of absorption but not the extent of absorption.

 

Option B. Cmax: The maximum concentration of the drug in plasma. It provides information on the peak level achieved but does not reflect the overall extent of absorption.

 

Option C. T1/2: The half-life of the drug, which is the time it takes for the plasma concentration to reduce by half. This parameter is related to the duration of action and elimination of the drug, not the extent of absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph is used to assess the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the bioavailability of the drug in the systemic circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration will not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral

 

Hepatic first-pass metabolism refers to the process where the concentration of a drug is greatly reduced before it reaches the systemic circulation. This occurs primarily when drugs are metabolized in the liver after being absorbed.

 

When a drug is taken orally, it is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract and then passes through the liver before reaching systemic circulation. This route is subject to significant hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual: This route involves placing a drug under the tongue, where it is absorbed directly into the bloodstream through the tissues beneath the tongue. It bypasses the liver initially, thus avoiding hepatic first-pass metabolism.

 

Option C. Intravenous (IV): Intravenous administration delivers a drug directly into the bloodstream, completely bypassing the liver initially. Therefore, it does not undergo first-pass metabolism.

 

Option D. Transdermal: Transdermal administration involves applying a drug through the skin (e.g., via a patch). The drug is absorbed directly into systemic circulation, bypassing the liver initially and thus avoiding first-pass metabolism.

 

Note: Please read the question carefully, which does not bypass means which undergoes first pass metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The route of administration that does not bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism is Oral. This is because drugs taken orally are absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and then pass through the liver where they may be metabolically altered before reaching the systemic circulation.

questions.text: For the action of heparin as an anticoagulant, availability of which of the following chemical substances is mandatory? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antithrombin-III

 

Heparin acts indirectly by activating Antithrombin-III. The heparin-antithrombin III then binds to the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway (10, 2, 9 ,11 and 12) and inactivates them. The anticoagulation action is exerted mainly by the inhibition of factor 10 as well as thrombin or factor 2. Therefore Antithrombin-Ill is mandatory for the action of heparin as an anticoagulant. Reduced antithrombin levels can lead to resistance.

 

In true heparin resistance, there is an actual blunting of heparin's anticoagulant effect. This occurs due to:

 

  • Low ATIII levels (most common cause)
  • Increased heparin-binding plasma proteins (acute phase reactants)
  • Increased heparin clearance (e.g., due to splenomegaly in liver disease)

 

Low ATIII levels could be due to decreased synthesis (hereditary, hepatic failure), increased consumption (DIC, MAHA, or in a bypass circuit) or increased loss (nephrotic syndrome).

 

The dose of heparin has to be increased to achieve therapeutic aPTT. Severe antithrombin deficiency may require antithrombin concentrate as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thrombin: Thrombin is a target of the heparin-antithrombin III complex, not a necessary cofactor for heparin's action.

 

Option B. Plasmin: Plasmin is involved in fibrinolysis (the breakdown of clots) and is not directly related to the anticoagulant action of heparin.

 

Option D. Thrombomodulin: Thrombomodulin is a receptor that binds thrombin and is involved in the activation of protein C, which has anticoagulant properties. However, it is not directly required for the action of heparin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The availability of antithrombin-III is mandatory for the anticoagulant action of heparin, as it forms a complex with heparin to inactivate key enzymes in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: A drug solution containing 500 mg/5 ml of the drug is given to you. You are provided with a 2 ml syringe (having 10 divisions for each mI). How many divisions of the 2 m syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to a patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 18

 

500 mg of the drug is present in 5ml of the solution.

 

Therefore, 180 mg will be present in (5/500) *180 = 1.8ml

 

In the syringe provided, 1ml = 10 divisions,

 

Therefore 1.8ml = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To deliver 180 mg of the drug using the provided 2 ml syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a GPCR? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Muscarinic

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors. Out of them, M1 and M3 act through Gq pathway and via the IP3/DAG pathway, whereas M2 and M4 act via Gi protein, that inhibits adenylyl cyclase leading to a decrease in the levels of cAMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotinic: Nicotinic receptors are ionotropic receptors, which means they are ion channel receptors and not GPCRs. They allow the passage of ions across the cell membrane when activated.

 

Option C. GABA-A: GABA-A receptors are also ionotropic receptors that function as chloride ion channels. They are not GPCRs.

 

Option D. Insulin: The insulin receptor is a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK), not a GPCR. It initiates a cascade of intracellular signaling upon binding insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that play a role in various physiological processes through different G-protein signaling pathways.

choices.text: Place generalized sutures in the area of bleeding
Elevate the endopelvic fascia by inserting fingers in the vagina
Insert a surgical drain to monitor further bleeding

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes a Burch colposuspension for stress urinary incontinence. During the procedure, there is significant bleeding in the space of Retzius, and the source of bleeding cannot be clearly visualized. What is the most appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevate the endopelvic fascia by inserting fingers in the vagina

 

Elevating the endopelvic fascia by inserting fingers in the vagina helps to identify the bleeding vessels by putting tension on the tissues, making it easier to visualize and grasp the bleeders, thus controlling the hemorrhage during Burch colposuspension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Call a vascular surgeon: In most cases of intraoperative bleeding in the space of Retzius, initial management is performed by the surgical team rather than calling a vascular surgeon unless the bleeding is extensive and cannot be controlled by routine methods.

 

Option B. Place generalized sutures in the area of bleeding: Applying generalized sutures without clear visualization may inadvertently damage other important structures, such as vessels or nerves, and does not guarantee control of the actual bleeding site.

 

Option D. Insert a surgical drain to monitor further bleeding: While inserting a surgical drain is useful for postoperative monitoring, it is not a solution for active bleeding during surgery. The first goal is to achieve hemostasis before the placement of a drain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During pelvic surgeries, if significant bleeding occurs in the space of Retzius and visualization is difficult, lifting the endopelvic fascia by placing fingers in the vagina can facilitate hemostasis.
  • The Burch colposuspension procedure aims to correct stress urinary incontinence by suspending the bladder neck.
  • Proper intraoperative management of bleeding can prevent complications, and it is essential to stabilize the patient before additional interventions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multifocal atrial tachycardia

 

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that occurs due to multiple abnormal electrical foci within the atria. It is characterized by the presence of at least three different P-wave morphologies on an ECG, as seen in this case. This condition often arises in patients with chronic pulmonary diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), especially during an acute illness like a fever or infection. The patient’s history of severe COPD and the ECG findings of varying P-wave morphologies are consistent with MAT.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: This condition presents with broad, wide QRS complexes and regular rhythm, which is not consistent with the ECG findings in this case.

 

Option C. Atrial fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation is another type of supraventricular tachycardia, but it is characterized by the absence of distinct P waves and irregular RR intervals. In this case, distinct P waves of different morphologies are present, ruling out atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia: Atrial tachycardia is a type of supraventricular tachycardia but typically arises from a single focus, leading to uniform P-wave morphologies. This is not consistent with the presence of multiple P-wave morphologies seen in MAT.

 

Educational Objective:


Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is commonly seen in patients with chronic pulmonary diseases and is characterized by irregular RR intervals and at least three distinct P-wave morphologies on an ECG. Recognizing these ECG features is essential for accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The image provided is from a mastoidectomy, a procedure where the middle ear structures are often visualized. The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear and is located between the malleus and the stapes. It has a distinctive structure with both a short process and a long process. The long process of the incus articulates with the head of the stapes, facilitating the transmission of sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. The arrow in the image points to the incus, which confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: The malleus is another middle ear ossicle, but it articulates with the tympanic membrane and the incus. The image, however, shows the incus, not the malleus.

 

Option C. Posterior Semicircular Canal: The posterior semicircular canal is part of the inner ear and is involved in balance, but it is not the structure indicated in the image.

 

Option D. Lateral Semicircular Canal: Similar to the posterior semicircular canal, the lateral semicircular canal is also part of the inner ear and plays a role in detecting head rotation, but it is not visible in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three ossicles in the middle ear and plays a crucial role in sound transmission by articulating with the malleus and stapes.

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the storage temperatures of blood components.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RBC 2-6°C, Platelet 20-22°C, FFP -30°C

 

The correct storage temperatures for various blood components are essential to ensure the viability and safety of transfusions:

 

  • Red Blood Cells (RBCs): Stored at 2-6°C to preserve their integrity and function for up to 42 days in CPD (Citrate-Phosphate-Dextrose) solution. This temperature range prevents hemolysis and preserves red cell function.
  • Platelets: Stored at 20-22°C with continuous gentle agitation to prevent clumping. This temperature ensures the platelets remain viable for up to 5-7 days.
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP): Stored at -30°C or lower, which maintains the activity of clotting factors. FFP can be stored for up to 1 year at this temperature.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recommended storage temperatures:

questions.text: The most common form of arthritis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis

 

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common form of arthritis, especially affecting individuals older than 75 years, with up to 80% experiencing it. OA is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage, which leads to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility in affected joints. It primarily affects weight-bearing joints such as the hips, knees, and spine, but can also involve the hands. Unlike inflammatory arthritis, it is not systemic, and joint involvement tends to be limited to specific areas rather than widespread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: This is an autoimmune inflammatory arthritis, but it is less common than osteoarthritis. It tends to affect smaller joints like the hands and wrists.

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis: This is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, and it is far less common compared to osteoarthritis.

 

Option C. Seronegative arthritis: This is a group of inflammatory joint diseases that do not have rheumatoid factor, including ankylosing spondylitis, but it is also much less common than osteoarthritis.

 

Educational Objective:


Osteoarthritis is the most prevalent form of arthritis, primarily affecting older adults. It involves the degeneration of joint cartilage, particularly in weight-bearing joints, and differs from inflammatory forms of arthritis like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with a fractured forearm and says she tripped and fell. On examination, you notice multiple cigarette burns on her forearm. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conduct a thorough examination

 

In cases of suspected child abuse, the first and most important step is to conduct a thorough physical examination to assess the extent of any injuries and identify any additional signs of abuse. Noticing multiple cigarette burns on the child’s forearm raises strong suspicion of physical abuse, and documenting all findings accurately is critical. After the physical examination, it is essential to follow up with a psychiatric evaluation and ensure the child's safety. In cases of confirmed or suspected abuse, further steps will include informing child protective services or relevant authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Seek a social worker’s help: While involving a social worker is important, it is not the immediate next step. The priority should be a thorough physical examination to assess the injuries.

 

Option C. Inform higher authorities immediately: Reporting to authorities is necessary, but only after conducting a detailed examination and collecting the necessary evidence.

 

Option D. Inform your colleagues: Although consulting colleagues might be helpful, the first step is a thorough examination to gather crucial details for further action.

 

Educational Objective:


When encountering a suspected case of child abuse, the first step should be a comprehensive physical examination to document and evaluate the injuries, followed by appropriate reporting and interventions to ensure the child's safety.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of steps in leukocyte migration: 

 

a. Stable adhesion
b. Integration activation by chemokine
c. Rolling
d. Migration through endothelium
questions.solution:
Ans. A) c, b, a, d

 

Leukocyte migration from the bloodstream to the tissue during inflammation is a multi-step process:

 

  1. Rolling (c): Leukocytes first "roll" along the endothelium. This process is mediated by selectins, which interact with glycoproteins on the leukocyte surface. Rolling allows leukocytes to slow down and move along the vessel wall.
  2. Activation by chemokines (b): Chemokines activate integrins on leukocytes, increasing their affinity for adhesion molecules on the endothelial surface.
  3. Stable adhesion (a): Once integrins are activated, leukocytes firmly adhere to the endothelium through integrin-mediated binding.

 

Migration through endothelium (d): Finally, leukocytes migrate across the endothelial barrier into the tissue through a process called diapedesis, following a chemotactic gradient to the site of inflammation.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Leukocyte migration involves rolling, chemokine-mediated integrin activation, stable adhesion, and migration across the endothelium, a crucial sequence in the immune response during inflammation.

questions.text: Anti-nuclear antibodies are required for the diagnosis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic lupus erythematosus

 

Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are autoantibodies that bind to cellular nuclear contents. They are present in over 95% of patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), making them a crucial marker for its diagnosis. A positive ANA test with a titer of at least 1:80 is an essential criterion for diagnosing SLE. According to the 2019 EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for SLE, a positive ANA test must be met alongside a set of additive criteria across 7 clinical and 3 immunologic domains. When these criteria achieve a total score of more than 10 points, SLE can be diagnosed. ANAs are recognized as the most sensitive antibodies for SLE diagnosis, although they lack specificity.

 

Additionally, specific antibodies such as Anti-Smith and Anti-dsDNA antibodies offer higher specificity for SLE, with Anti-Smith being the most specific, followed closely by Anti-dsDNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scleroderma:  Scleroderma, also known as systemic sclerosis, is characterized by antibodies specific to anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-centromere antibodies, which are highly specific for systemic sclerosis. ANA may be positive in some cases of scleroderma, but it is not a criterion for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is primarily associated with rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. ANAs may occasionally be present in RA patients, but they are not diagnostic criteria for RA.

 

Option D. Sjogren's syndrome: In Sjogren's syndrome, the specific autoantibodies are Anti-Ro and Anti-La. While ANAs may also be positive in Sjogren's syndrome, they are not a diagnostic criterion for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are a required diagnostic criterion for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and are present in over 95% of SLE patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatic insufficiency

 

The presentation of chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea indicates a malabsorption syndrome. Key diagnostic tests include the D-xylose test, duodenal biopsy, and Schilling test to help identify the underlying pathology. In this case:

 

  1. Normal D-xylose test – This suggests an intact small intestinal mucosa, as D-xylose is a monosaccharide absorbed directly by the intestinal lining without requiring digestive enzymes.
  2. Normal duodenal biopsy – This finding further excludes small intestinal conditions like celiac disease or intestinal lymphangiectasia, which typically show abnormalities on biopsy.
  3. Abnormal Schilling test – An abnormal Schilling test indicates impaired absorption of vitamin B12. Pancreatic enzymes are required to release vitamin B12 from its bound form, facilitating its absorption. In pancreatic insufficiency, a lack of these enzymes leads to an abnormal Schilling test, which may normalize after pancreatic enzyme supplementation.

 

Pancreatic insufficiency, often associated with chronic pancreatitis, causes a deficiency in pancreatic enzymes, which are crucial for the digestion and absorption of nutrients, particularly fats. This deficiency leads to steatorrhea and an abnormal Schilling test, aligning with the clinical findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac disease:  In celiac disease, the D-xylose test would typically be decreased, and duodenal biopsy would show abnormal findings such as villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and epithelial cell damage. This makes celiac disease an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option B. Ulcerative colitis:  Ulcerative colitis affects the colon and does not typically lead to fat malabsorption or steatorrhea, as fat absorption occurs in the small intestine. Additionally, it does not affect the Schilling or D-xylose tests.

 

Option C. Intestinal lymphangiectasia : This condition involves abnormal lymphatic function, leading to malabsorption, but it would show an abnormal duodenal biopsy with findings such as dilated lymphatics and clubbed villi. The normal biopsy here rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:
